Reviews.Title: Our Second Chromebook
Reviews.Author: A. Dent "Aragorn"
Reviews.Content: HP's Chromebook 11 is my second Chromebook because, after one year with Samsung's Chromebook I came to realize that not only a Chromebook does almost everything a laptop or a PC or a tablet would do for me but it does it cheaper, usually faster and better, almost always worry-free and very much in style._____________________________________________________UPDATE (Dec 26, 2013): I am glad to see HP's 11-inch Chromebook available again. We've been using ours all throughout the charger 'crisis' and we are as happy with it today if not happier than we were on 'day one'. More than two months later, HP's Chromebook 11 continues to be a beautiful little device with a great display that continues to do most of what I require during my off-work hours. It traveled with me on my vacation and will travel with me again and it's there (on couch or on my bedside table) when I need it._____________________________________________________WHY A CHROMEBOOK?There's so much to say here but let me make a quick summary. And never forget that we are talking about an 'under 300' device here because, yes, anything that costs 3-4-5 times as much should do better most of the time.˕ My Chromebook is my most used computer excluding work hours and by 'computer' I mean PCs, laptops and tablets.˕ Malware, spyware, adware-free. Since nothing is really 'installed' on the Chromebook, I can't see how one would ever be infected. I am now using my Chromebook to open suspicious emails or click on dubious URLs that I don't dare touch from a laptop.˕ Extremely safe OS. I don't know if this is common knowledge but Google is constantly challenging hackers to crack their OS. As far as I know, Chromium wasn't cracked yet.˕ Easy to share among any number of users without any concerns of compromising privacy. If you have a Google account, you simply sign in and you are going to be within your own, personal environment.˕ Constantly updated and upgraded. Google updates Chromium every few weeks and I found my Chromebook actually getting better all the time rather than slowly fall into obsolescence. HP's Chromebook will not replace Samsung's, it will be used by another family member who really, really wanted one after watching my happy relationship with our first one.˕ Nearly maintenance free. Whenever I don't use a tablet or even a laptop for a while, they tend to get very busy for a while once I turn them back on. Tablets, especially, are almost impossible to use until all those dozens of updates/upgrades process. Not the case for Chromebooks. Whatever upgrades may take place don't hit my Chromebook. Whenever I call up an app, I get it in its latest version.˕ The attached keyboard helps a lot. Yes, you can pair a keyboard and even a mouse to a tablet but the Chromebook's keyboard is always there, it negates the need of a stand or even some protecting case.˕ Chromium is streamlined and efficiently focused where it matters, on the everyday uses most of us need a 'computer' most of the time.˕ Chromium being such a streamlined OS, browsing and running apps on a Chromebook is in fact faster than off a PC/laptop/tablet of equivalent specs.˕ Relatively low prince, 11.6" display and light weight seem to be just about right for something that typically you'd be using to browse the Web while watching TV or take to and from school.WHY NOT A CHROMEBOOK?Yes, Chromebooks can't do everything. Google's productivity suites notwithstanding, they are mainly and they are best at media consumption rather than production. Nobody should buy a Chromebook and expect to be able to edit video or perform some heavy word processing or do some hard-core gaming. There are other machines and devices for such tasks. My experience is that a Chromebook can't do 'everything'. Tablets are more portable, PCs and laptops are more powerful but, to me, my Chromebook is the most fun to use and it's likely to stay this way. I am not going to call it my 'second' or 'third' or 'first' computer but, objectively, it's the one most use outside business hours if what we measure is 'hours'.HP's CHROMEBOOK 11I haven't spent a lot of time with HP's but, from the start, it was a very familiar feeling. HPs is not 'exactly like' Samsung's but it's easily recognizable as a Chromebook.Here are some changes:˕ USB-based charging. This is a BIG thing. The biggest negative in the case of Samsung's Chromebook was the proprietary charger. HP's USB-based charging allows the use of most off-the-shelf chargers so there's a lot less to worry.˕ Better quality display. When compared to Samsung's the colors are sharper and brighter and you can view the screen from almost any angle left/right or up/down.˕ Nicer keyboard. It's the same layout but the keys seem to have a little more travel. As a touch typist I am comfortable with both but, on a blind test, I would probably pick HP's over Samsung's.˕ Somewhat more stylish design. I got the black model and I like both the color and the color accents. Some prefer 'silver' but they are both Okay as far as I can tell.˕ Fewer ports. There are no USB 3.0 or HDMI ports on the HP's even though my understanding is that you can, in fact output HDMI through the Micro USB. This may be a big deal for some and they should get Samsung's if that's the case. Speaking for myself, I never felt a need to output HDMI off my Chromebook, ever. Same for USB data transfers.Overall, I am very pleased with HPs device. The lack of USB 3.0 and HDMI ports amount to a big 'nothing' to me and their absence is balanced and surpassed by the non-proprietary charging method, much nicer display and better keyboard.RATINGI am not going to compare HP's Chromebook with the Pixel or some top of the line laptop. I noticed that many 'pro' reviewers are complaining because Chromebooks and this particular one are not 'high end' and aren't as nice as the Pixel and such. Well... did anyone check the prices? So, yes, let me make a 'duh' statement: this Chromebook is not as good as devices that sell for 3 times or 4 times as much so anyone who doesn't mind paying more should pay more and get one of those. Even though... look at some reasons above for why one my prefer a Chromebook to a laptop or a tablet, regardless of price.HPs is a five-star to me because it's at least as good and in some way better than my now one year old, often used and much trusted Samsung. The thirty dollars price difference between the two can be justified by HP's supporting USB charging, its much nicer display and its marginally better keyboard. As far as performance, they both appear to be up to the task and they both played Netflix movies flawlessly over Wi-Fi and cast them to the big TV through Chromecast (no need of an HDMI cable for that) - I mention it because I just tried that.Chromebooks are not for everyone and they are not a universal computing device but, if used for what they are meant to be used, they are as good and as revolutionary as tablets._____________________________________________________CHROMEBOOK vs. CHROMEBOOK (HPs vs. Acer C720I had the opportunity to play with Acer's Chromebook for a day and was therefore able to compare them side by side.- Advantage HP -˕ Looks and design. HPs looks much better in my view, you have color choices and that's that.˕ Display. Same size, same resolution but HPs display is brighter, sharper and, most importantly, can be viewed from almost any angle. Not the case with Acer's.˕ Charging. The ability to charge HPs Chromebook through almost any USB charger is very important to me. Acer's charger is proprietary.- Advantage Acer -˕ Horsepower. Acer's appears to be faster and it should be given its faster processor.˕ Ports. You get HDMI out, USB 3.0 and SD card slot, all of them missing on HP's machine.˕ Price. At least at launch, Acer's was selling for less.I would say it's a tie when it comes to the keyboard and track pad's feel.Acer's machine has the advantage if you are more 'productivity oriented' and need expansion capabilities (ports) and more raw CPU power. You would prefer the HP if you want a Chromebook mainly for fun and casual activities where looks, the availability of a charger and, very importantly, the quality of the display count more._____________________________________________________NOTES:- Like most Chromebooks, this one too comes with a free 100GB in Google's cloud for two years. I didn't take advantage of that offer and I'm not going to go for this one, simply because I have no use of 'cloud' storage that goes beyond Gmail at this time.- While Chromebooks are immune to viruses and other forms of malware, you are as tracked and 'monetized' while on a Chromebook as you are when browsing from your laptop or tablet or phone. However, there are ways to disrupt and confuse the trackers and my two favorite extensions these days are Disconnect Search (or Disconnect.me) that makes it impossible for Google to log your search activities and DoNotTrackMe which does what the name implies. Worth trying.

Reviews.Title: Beautifully Designed, Google at its best.
Reviews.Author: Joel Rodriguez "Joelyesca"
Reviews.Content: First of all, I believe that words can't express how satisfied I am with my new HP Chromebook. It is super thin and light and extremely beautiful. It is so practical that I can charge this laptop with the same charger of my smartphone and the other way around. This is the best laptop on the go.The screen is very sharp, bright and high quality. Keyboard feels great when typing, speakers sound comes from the keyboard which makes this Chromebook completely sealed. There's no holes, moving parts, or anything that makes any noise.Chrome OS has had a lot of improvements since last year. There a lot of offline apps, better notifications and a lot of awesome extensions. Free Google Drive 100Gb is still awesome.I want to acknowledge that this is not a high performance laptop and is not suitable for high demanding 3D gamers. But for the price you will be fully satisfied because obviously this Chromebook has a really affordable price and is very pretty and performs almost all the task a regular computer does(and some extras that traditional computers doesn't).One thing worth mention that this computer excels is Sound. Speakers are very rich, precise, loud and clear. Music lovers will enjoy the clarity of the music. You can really enjoy watching a movie due to the richness of the image and the quality of the sound...I love this Chromebook because it just do the job well done!Any questions please feel free to ask it in the comments below section...

Reviews.Title: Perfect...
Reviews.Author: Deron Dantzler
Reviews.Content: I am an IT professional (web/application developer), and I must say that I love this new Chromebook. I purchased a Samsung 11 inch Chromebook 4 months ago and have been using it as my primary home machine ever since. The Samsung was great, but the screen was the Achilles heel. I can say that this screen is the same approximate quality of an 11 inch MacBook Air. I can't make out an advantage between the two screens. That is awesome for this price. The design is perfect, and the speakers sound great for a small laptop.It's my opinion that tablets are great for surfing the Internet and reading, but even though you may add a keyboard they are basically useless for productivity. Multi-tasking is the downfall for those devices and it really needs to get sorted out. The Chromebook is more like a tablet in a laptop disguise, and "multi-tasks" well. Of course it's running one core application (Chrome), but you can use multiple windows, etc. That's very helpful when copying and pasting content, and using productivity applications. For the general public that likes to surf the net, work with documents, write e-mails, etc. this is a highly recommended machine. Work can be done on the device. I also teach college courses both online and brick and mortar, and this device has been my go-to machine for grading, interacting with students, etc. That goes to show the power of the device for the typical office user. It works for advanced users like me if you take it for what it is... A damn quality piece of hardware for the price that offers a far more robust productivity experience than any competitively priced tablet.If your curious, my usage pattern for technology has now evolved to: Smartphone, Small tablet, Chromebook. No need for a large tablet. Small tablet is primarily for bed and couch surfing and using as an e-reader. Smartphone is my main on the go unit. Chromebook is my primary computer. When I'm at work, I primarily use my corporate PC. My wife's primary computer is a MacBook, so if there's a time when I need to do something more intense (on rare occasions I need to do some web graphical interface design at home) then I use her MacBook or Remote Desktop on the Chromebook to my corporate machine.If you're on the fence, I say give it a shot.

Reviews.Title: The next generation of Chromebooks - A complete review
Reviews.Author: Cenile D. Mentia
Reviews.Content: ==UPDATE 12/26/13== Well, the HP Chromebook is back on the shelves after the whole issue with the chargers overheating. After a couple months with this Chromebook and the other model, I still say the Acer Chromebook is a better value--but for those who don't multitask as often and just prefer a well designed laptop for a low price (it does look good!), this is probably the best model for you.This is getting to be a long review, so I've split it up into multiple sections. Feel free to jump to the section which you think will help you the most.==CONTENTS==1) Upgrades from last year2) Alternative models3) First impressions4) Conclusion5) SummaryI'll be updating this review as I use the Chromebook more often as well, so check back once in a while! As always, feel free to ask questions in the comments section, and I'll be happy to answer them.==UPGRADES FROM LAST YEAR==In 2012, with the Samsung Chromebook becoming the #1 best selling laptop on Amazon, it seemed like there was hope after all for the Chromebooks. It was something that not many people expected, but the thin, silent design, combined with a decent battery life and a low price point managed to attract enough people to give Chromebooks a chance.One year later, the time has come for its successor--the HP Chromebook 11. Is it a worthy successor? This review will take a closer look at what changed over the last year as well as explore some of the alternative options.Let's start with the hardware. The design of this Chromebook is completely different compared to Samsung's model from last year. This is partially because it's made by HP, but also because Google teamed up with HP to design this new Chromebook. There's two color choices now, black and white. If you pick the white version, you also have the option to add Google-colored accents to the edges of the keyboard, while the black version is more understated, with an all black finish. Whether you like the new design or not is subjective, but it does retain the thinness (.69 inches) and is actually .1 pounds lighter than the previous Samsung model. There's also a new LED light bar on the back, similar to the Pixel. It lights up with the Google colors when it's on, and it looks pretty nice. Personally, I think it's a well designed laptop. It's simple, lightweight, and the unsightly bump from last year's model is gone.The keyboard and touchpad are still extremely good. It's comfortable to type on, and overall has a much sturdier feel due to a new magnesium frame that they put in to support the plastic shell. There were some complaints about the Samsung model from last year regarding how flimsy it felt and how easy it was to bend it, and they definitely improved it here. Also, they've moved the speakers to underneath the keyboard, similar to how Apple does it. This way, the speakers do not get muffled when you put the notebook on your laps. Speaker quality is actually pretty decent for a sub-$300 laptop, but headphones are still going to be the obvious first choice for audiophiles.Another major improvement is the screen. Google's making a big deal about the brightness of the new screen, but it truly is better than last year's model. Though it retains the same 1366x768 resolution (which is fine for a 11 inch laptop), the viewing angles and the contrast is much better. It is a glossy screen though, so unless you absolutely loved the more matte feel of last year's model, then the screen's also a big improvement.The best hardware improvement for me personally is the new power port. It's now charged through a Micro USB cable, a cable that's currently used to charge most Android phones as well as the Amazon Kindles. As someone who travels a lot, this would mean just packing one cable to charge all my devices, something that I think adds a lot of convenience. Another advantage is that the abundance of Micro USB cables makes it easy to find a replacement should you ever lose it(you probably have one lying around in your house!). Note that it does charge slower if you use another cable: the one that comes with this Chromebook has been optimized for it. With that being said, the HP Chromebook 11 does lose the HDMI port found in the previous model, but it's still possible to connect it to your TV. To do so, you'd have to buy a Slimport adapter and then connect the HDMI cable from there. It's not a big hassle, but it's still something worth mentioning.All of these changes mentioned above have been mostly good and welcomed improvements to last year's model, but perhaps it's the parts that haven't changed which are the most disappointing. Unfortunately, Google has decided to not upgrade any of the internal aspects of the Chromebook, so it still retains the same ARM based processor found last year's model, the 16GB of flash storage, and the 2GB of RAM. Battery life remains more or less the same as well, at around 6 hours. Considering the brisk pace technology moves at, I think it's hugely disappointing that Google is still using last year's chips, and it's the one major flaw with this Chromebook. One of the biggest changes in technology this year was the introduction of Intel's 4th generation Haswell processors, giving solid processing power while drastically increasing power efficiency. The new Macbooks are using it, and some of the new Chromebooks are too, increasing their battery life to around 9 hours per charge. One might argue that Chromebooks don't require much processing power, but with websites and web apps becoming more advanced every day, I think it's disappointing that none of the internal hardware was upgraded. Note that overall performance isn't bad, but it's not great either. It's the exact same as last year's model - most websites I tried run smoothly, but some of the more graphically heavy websites stutter when you're trying to scroll. HD video playback is relatively steady, but if you have too many tabs open, the quality suffers. For the pages most people visit, like Facebook, Youtube, Gmail, etc., I thought this Chromebook handled it pretty well as long as I didn't have too many tabs open.In regards to the software, this is still running Chrome OS, and if you used any of the Chromebooks before, you'd be familiar with it's capabilities and limitations. There's no real changes here, since all Chromebooks are continuously updated with the most recent version of Chrome OS, but for those looking at the Chromebooks for the first time, here's a little rundown on how the Chrome operating system works. At its core, it's the Chrome web browser, and only the Chrome web browser. Though the pictures in the advertisements shows a desktop and wallpaper, don't be fooled: it's not a traditional PC. Therefore, if you use programs like Microsoft Office, Photoshop, iTunes, etc., know that you won't be able to use any of those programs on a Chromebook. However, there are substitutes for most of those programs online, such as Google Docs, Picasa, Google Music, etc. The advantage of having such a simple system is speed: it boots up in less than 10 seconds, and you're instantly connected to the web (provided you have Wi-Fi). Therefore, if most of what you do on a computer is browse the web anyways (Facebook, E-mail, Youtube, etc.), then a Chromebook allows you to do all of that very quickly.Overall, this Chromebook is definitely an improvement over last year's Samsung model, but the lack of internal changes makes it really hard to recommend if you're looking to upgrade from the Samsung model. For people looking into Chromebooks for the first time, I'd say that this isn't a bad model - it's relatively cheap at $279, it's well designed, and it's overall performance is still solid. For people looking for a "cute" second computer, I do think this is a great model. However, I'd still recommend giving the other models announced this year a look (see below).==ALTERNATIVE MODELS==Even though this is Google's new flagship Chromebook - the one they're promoting as the Chromebook "for everyone", there are other options coming out.Acer's C720 Chromebook (Acer C720 Chromebook (11.6-Inch, Haswell micro-architecture, 4GB))I've been using this model for the last couple days and I must say I prefer this model over the Hp model. It's just so much zippier: websites load faster, scrolling is more responsive, and it handles multiple tabs better. It also has better battery life and more input/output ports. Sure the screen isn't as good, but it's not terrible either. Unless you really desire an attention-catching device, I'd recommend the Acer Chromebook over this model. I've written a full review for the Acer, so feel free to read it for a closer look.HP's Chromebook 14 (HP Chromebook 14 (Snow White))HP announced this as an update to last year's 14 inch model, which was moderately successful. They've completely redesigned it, and I think it looks much more elegant. It'll come in multiple colors for $299. It'll also include the new Haswell processors, giving it a 9-hour battery life. I think this is a great model for those who want a larger screen and do not mind the increased weight.Additional notes:Google also packages this Chromebook 11 with some extra perks, including 12 sessions of GoGo In-flight Wi-Fi, as well as 100GB of Google Drive storage for 2 years. If you are a frequent flyer, those 12 sessions alone makes the Chromebook pretty cost-efficient. I'm not certain if the other Chromebook models include the GoGo WiFi, but they all include the Google Drive storage. Also something worth mentioning is that this HP Chromebook 11 model is fanless due to its processor, so it's absolutely silent. The other models do have fans, but in my opinion, the sound difference is negligible.==FIRST IMPRESSIONS==When I first heard about this Chromebook, I was pretty excited. I looked at a bunch of pictures, saw the price tag, and I thought to myself, "Now here's the Chromebook I've been waiting for". Prior to this, I've used the Samsung Chromebook S3 as well as the original CR-48 Chromebook test model, mainly for taking notes in class. After opening the box and turning it on for the first time, I was ecstatic, because to be honest, this screen looked great, especially compared to the older models. The Chromebook in general looked great. I loved the color bar in the back, the clean design, and the keyboard. It was light and portable, and it looked very...attractive (as attractive as a computer can be I suppose). Setting it up was easy as well: you connect to your Wi-Fi, enter in your Google credentials, and then it syncs with your Google account, and all your bookmarks and apps are automatically transferred over. Anyone who's used a Chromebook before would be used to this.Bringing it to class was also a pleasure. It fits into one of my smaller bags, and it was light enough to be comfortable to carry. I thought the keyboard and trackpad were pretty awesome - they remind me of the Apple's keyboard, and I think that's a pretty high compliment. I'm a fast touch typist, and I was able to maintain my normal WPM with few errors while taking notes. Midway through the day though, I was working on a research project and had a bunch of tabs open and the Chromebook began to feel a bit slow: pages were loading slower and the scrolling wasn't as smooth. I attribute to the fact that Google decided to use last year's chips as I mentioned in the section above, as this was something that would happen with the Samsung model as well. This was frustrating for me, because I thought surely by now, Chrome would run smoothly on Chrome OS. This is the sole reason I'm giving this model 3 stars. I got around 5.5 hours of battery life, so that's a bit less than advertised. Nevertheless, I did find the charging cable useful, and I was able to use it to charge both my phone and the computer.==CONCLUSION==With this year's updates, I'm sure Chromebooks will continue to be a rising star. This model, looks especially good. It's one of the best looking laptops that I've seen at this price point, and really raises the bar for low-end Chromebooks. However, if looks aren't everything for you, some of the other models equipped with the Haswell processors are especially worth looking into. While this HP Chromebook 11 is well designed - the screen is great, the speakers are decent, the keyboard is great - I'm slightly concerned about it's performance.When someone buys a laptop, they expect it to last them at least a couple of years, and I'm not sure how long a computer with a chip from the previous generation will be able to keep up.==SUMMARY==The Good:- Great screen- Great keyboard- Great sound for a sub-$300 laptop- Overall design is eye catchingThe Bad:- The processor is outdated, leading to sluggish performance at times- Cannot be taken apart, parts are hard to replace (Cannot increase RAM for example)- Less ports compared to previous generations- Battery life is good compared to last year's models, but only mediocre compared to this year's models.Overall:The HP Chromebook 11, with its solid keyboard and fantastic screen, allows you to get some serious work done -- and look good while doing it. If you can deal with a mediocre processor and battery life (and of course, Chrome OS), this is a great model. Otherwise, look elsewhere.Score: 3.5/5

Reviews.Title: A PERFECT device if you know what you're getting
Reviews.Author: Ozzy
Reviews.Content: First and foremost, if you're looking for something to use as your primary device, go look at something else. This won't cut it if you need a do-everything computer. If that statement doesn't apply to you, then read on:PROS (there's a lot)- The price - For less than most tablets, you get a lot more functionality.- Great design - There are no visible screws, and the glossy white color is reminiscent of the older MacBooks.- Extremely light - I think it weighs about the same as a MacBook Air, but it feels lighter to me.- A stunning display - For this price point, I still can't believe how gorgeous it looks.- Well designed keyboard - Super comfortable to type on and the keys have just the right amount of spring to them.- Surprisingly loud - The speakers are under the keyboard, meaning you don't get muffled sound. No tinniness either.- It's built with Chrome - If you already use Chrome, you'll feel right at home. All your favorite things carry over!- Has two full size USB 2.0 ports. I've plugged in my external hard drive to watch movies and listen to music.- It charges via micro-USB - Finally, you can use the same charger for both your phone and your laptop!CONS- Battery life - Even after trying multiple configurations, the most I've been able to get is a little less than five hours.- Trackpad - I raised the sensitivity to the max setting, and while it helped a lot, it still isn't the best.- Only 16GB of built in storage - It comes with two years of 100GB of Google Drive storage, but it would have been nice to have a little more on board to have access to some things while not connected to the internet. For those wondering, you don't lose all your things saved to Google Drive after the two years are up, you're just not able to upload any more content unless you start paying for more storage.Hope this helps those who are on the fence! (Review typed and uploaded on my Chromebook)

Reviews.Title: Great keyboard but needs a better CPU.
Reviews.Author: Terry Poulin "Spidey01"
Reviews.Content: I've had one of these for a good 3 or 4 months now with moderate usage. Was a little sad Best Buy only had it in White/Blue; since I wanted White/Green.The good:  - A gorgeous 11.6" HD screen.  - Long battery life.  - Keyboard is AWESOME.  - MicroUSB charging and MyDP/Slimport port.The bad:  - Performance is limited.  - Only USB 2.0 slots.The screen is one of the best laptop screens I've seen. Much more like your typical $400 to $600 tablet and unlike most laptops. In fact, I have seen much worse screens on $1500 laptops!Battery life tends to be long enough that I don't worry. I often see estimates of between 3 and 4 hours and can easily get over 6. Hooked up to a monitor and mouse, I can almost get through a workday with it, using the Chromebook as a Secure Shell (SSH) terminal.Keyboard is something to write home about. If you do a lot of typing, which for me, is 12 to 16 hours a day computer use. You will really appreciate this keyboard and wish you could steal it for other products, lol. This is the kinda laptop you want to use the original keyboard because it is just so good -- rather that dock, slap the lid, and move on.Along with the screen, one reason I chose this over the Samsung model, is the MicroUSB charging. It charges the same way that a standard compliant phone does; read virtually everything in the last several years without an Apple logo. The supplied charger is also a 3A, which is two the three times or more than typical phone chargers. If you use a Slimport / MyDP adapter you can hook it up to a monitor pretty easy too. Works kinda like MHL on a phone, except being DisplayPort based, it works well with VGA/D-SUB, DVI, and HDMI displays; where as MHL goes down hill if your monitor lacks HDMI.The devices processor is the real let down and only strong negative. If you are a regular user, it will likely be fine. For regular web surfing it is perfectly fine. What chokes it is heavy lifting: things like Evernote and Google Plus. Having many Chrome extensions in the background will basically give you a 22~25 second load time on Google+ (2013). I found that removing the Google Voice, Hangouts, and Google Cast extensions really helped. Without any extensions loaded the performance of loading Google+ and Gmail is more like the Celeron 847 based Chromebooks. Google+ can load in under 10 seconds that way. On the upside however thanks to the processor, the battery life is awesome and doesn't go down hill so fast, like every Core i5 machine I've used in the 'Bridge family. Trying to do audio playback and opening a lot of tabs can cause stutters in the output sometimes. That seems to be when the processor cranks up and runs out of headroom, not from having 2GB of RAM.As a consequence of the Exynos 5 Dual SoC, we only get support for USB 2. I would personally like USB 3.0 ports but frankly, for a Chromebook and the price, I can live with that ^_^.If you have any issues with performance, wait for a newer version. A Snapdragon 800 or Exynos 5 Octa design would be a nice upgrade; be it either 2GB or 3GB RAM. I think a more powerful SoC would have been a better deal for this price vs the Samsung mode. But eh, we got an awesome screen and solid build quality.

Reviews.Title: Lasted less than 30 days
Reviews.Author: 4StarDad "Dad to 4 Stars"
Reviews.Content: I bought this for my daughter so she would have something for homework, research, music and entertainment. Loved the idea of cloud storage so everything was backed up automagically. My daughter LOVED it. Great little Chromebook... until it died.Less than 30 days later, it wouldn't power on. When plugged in to the charger, no lights, no life. I did some research and read about the (old) charger problems but we have the newer, square charger. I looked for a replacement charger online, but couldn't find anything. Then I looked on HP's site and couldn't find anything. I eventually called Google and got a very nice (really) young man who was more than willing to work with me. We plugged it into a 2 AMP smartphone charge with no luck. We tried a cold reset with no luck. He escalated to tier-2 support and I worked with another nice young man. We went through several iterations until he said they're going to send us a new Chromebook (and charger). Great! I PDF's my receipt and emailed it to him and he said it would be shipped 2nd Day Air "as soon as it was available."That should have been my warning right there. He couldn't tell me when it would be available. It's now a week later and so I emailed him for an update. He said he still doesn't know, but if it takes longer than 30 days to please let him know. 30 DAYS!!??!! It didn't even LAST 30 DAYS!!! Guess what prompted me to write my review? Buyers beware.************************Update: May 23, 2014After not receiving our replacement even after several weeks, I started turning to social media. I posted a review on HP's site and their site admin wrote me back saying they would look into the issue and see if they could help. I received a replacement within 48 hours of that post. It's now been a couple of weeks and we're starting to see charger issues again, with the plug having to be plugged in "just right" for it to take a charge. I don't have high hopes for the replacement at this point, but we'll have to wait and see. Having read the most recent reviews, it appears IMHO this particular piece of HP engineering is suffering from a design and/or supplier problem.************************Update: May 30, 2014HP Chromebook 11 #2 is now dead after ~2 weeks, again due to charging issues. We've tried 3 different micro-USB chargers to no avail. The Chromebook charger itself seems to be okay, as it will charge at least a couple of cell phones, but the Chromebook won't work. We've also found that while plugged in, the Chromebook will sometimes suddenly turn off, and that also often happens when unplugging it. Seems like there is likely a short in the charging socket.I called Google again and opened a new case. I have to give them props for courtesy and speaking English as their native language, but once again we're in a holding pattern to receive a replacement. This is getting old very quickly.

Reviews.Title: Perfect for me.
Reviews.Author: Sean
Reviews.Content: I purchased this Chromebook unsure if it would be the right fit for me, and after 2 weeks I am positive that it is. As a college student, I didn't want to spend too much money replacing my broken laptop. At $279, this HP Chromebook is a steal.What I use it for:1. Web-browsing.- Extremely fast, can have multiple tabs open at once with no lag.2. Writing papers (Google docs).- No problems with the keyboard. Easy to type and very smooth.3. Making powerpoints (Google presentation), (Google) Spreadsheets.4. Watching movies/TV (Netflix, Amazon Prime, AVI files from USB, etc.)- The screen is just as good as my Macbook Pro's was. Perfect video quality.After my laptop broke, in an effort to replace it, I bought a tablet that was almost $200 more than this Chromebook, and returned it out of disappointment. After 2 weeks with this Chromebook, nothing with it has been a disappointment. I am pretty tech savvy but by no means a "tech nerd," and I would highly recommend this Chromebook, whether you are on a budget or not.

Reviews.Title: For the money, a great deal for devotees to Google
Reviews.Author: TobycW
Reviews.Content: I will admit, my loyalty to google started with the search engine, solidified with Gmail and the Chrome browser, and went totally all-in with Android.  In this context, let me say that I love the Chromebook 11, my first Chromebook, after owning it for just 2 days.I have put it through it's paces and have to say it is a great alternative to tablets for those prefering the traditional laptop form factor.Points of discussion:1-portability.  The Chromebook 11 is the perfect size, weight and thickness for travel.  Basically a little thicker and heavier than most 10" tablets but not by much.2-charger.  Using a micro-usb charger is a stroke of genius.  Rated at 3A, it will charge my Chromebook, my smartphone and my tablet.  Huge plus in my book.  Certainly better than the power brick most Win laptops come with and many tablets have.3-screen.  This screen compares favorably to my original Nexus 7.  It is bright with good viewing angle.  It is my better than my full size Gateway laptop, and it is what I consider a "premium" display.  Bright, colorful, sharp.4-sound.  Every laptop I've used suffered in sound quality and volume.  The Chromebook has passable sound quality but is much louder from the fact that sound emanates through the keyboard.  Plenty loud for my purposes.  A negative is that sound stutters if the processor is taxed.  Unfortunately, this includes any sort of web browsing while you have music playing in the background.  I didn't think audio amounted to a huge processor load and wonder if this isn't some glitch that can be fixed--after all, I listen to music and browse all the time with my smartphone.5-Google.  You have to love google or forget it.  That means using Chrome, Gmail, Drive, Music, Google Docs etc.  If you do already, great.  If not, you better jump on board or don't buy this.  If you are thinking about making the transition, definitely search the internet for quirks ie. specific file types, workarounds, etc.  May not be "doable" for you.6-Keyboard.  Solid chicklet-style keyboard.  Fullsize.  Definitely better than most $500 laptops out there.  I love it.7-Trackpad.  I was always a mouse guy.  I immediately paired the Microsoft bluetooth mouse with the Chromebook as soon as I set it up.  But this trackpad is easy to use, so much so that I may ditch the mouse.  First trackpad that I'm starting to really dig--just after 2 days!8-Ports.  Not a lot.  Just 2 USB 2.0 ports.  No SD card reader.  No HDMI.  Not a problem for me since I am used to using Google Drive or a USB thumbdrive.9-Processing speed.  This is not a fast computer.  Some webpages take noticeably longer to load.  I feel this is the main downside to this laptop.Bottom line, I considered a high end Ultrabook (namely, the Samsung ATIV Plus or the LENOVO YOGA 2 PRO) but in the end, the Chromebook satisfies 90% of my travel needs, and 100% of my sitting-in-front-of-the-TV-browsing needs.  Lastly, I bought my Chromebook 11 from Google Play.  After having an issue with my Nexus 7 after 11 months of ownership, I will say that Google customer service is top notch and a pleasure to deal with.  Something to think about.  I did have to pay tax and shipping though.

Reviews.Title: Do NOT buy
Reviews.Author: Karl A. Idsvoog
Reviews.Content: Amazon ships this with a recalled charger.  You open the box.  There's a note telling younot to use the charger and directing you to go online and to request the replacement which it says you'll receive within 30 days.In other words, Amazon ships a computer to you knowing in advance that it cannot be used.

Reviews.Title: LOVE my Chrome book
Reviews.Author: Natalie Simons
Reviews.Content: I bought the chromebook to use for paying bills, email, games, and networking (mostly).  What are the things I LOVE about this product???1)  Battery holds charge extremely long and charges extremely fast2)  Very easy initial set up3)  Open it up and boom you can be on the internet....4)  Do NOT have to purchase any anti virus crap....One of the best purchases I made this year and SOOO affordable!!! If you are considering I would not hesitiate (although I have not used it for more than basic functions)

Reviews.Title: great for my portable pc needs
Reviews.Author: J. Doughten
Reviews.Content: pros-light-thin-looks good-pretty quick-good displaycons-hd video will stutter slightly with several tabs open.overall very pleased with this chromebook.

Reviews.Title: Very Pleased with 2nd Chromebook
Reviews.Author: Conrad Lopez "Conrad"
Reviews.Content: I have waited about a month to write this as my initial enthusiasm for this device was just over the top. I wanted to let it settle in a bit.This is my second Chromebook (Samsung the first). From the moment I opened it up it just felt solid. I am an Apple Fanboy and I had been put off by the Samsung build. It looked old a couple of weeks after I got it. The HP11 still looks brand new.Let's not get carried away though. This is a basic computer. It is perfect for those who surf the Internet and write  emails. I use the full array of Google Apps though and while I occasionally run into a rough patch it is usually about me getting used to the concept of everything being online. There is usually a solution.The negatives? I wish the usb ports were 3.0 and I wish they were powered more so I could charge my iPhone while working with the system. I wish there was an SD card slot but I'm looking into getting a reader which I think will solve that problem.What do I like? First of all it is featherweight. It is the lightest little guy I have ever owned. The screen is spectacular, especially for a $279 computer. Be warned though, that it does reflect quite a bit in certain circumstances. I have trouble using it out on my patio. The Samsung with it's matted screen is better for that. (Cool thing about Chrome is moving between the two computers is just like using one system). The keyboard is just right. The touchpad is pretty good. All of those things are subjective though. To each his own.The design is sporty and unique versus trying to be an Apple lookalike. People regularly ask me what it is.I'm very, very happy with the whole Chromebook concept and especially this version of it. At this price point I'll be able to swap it out for newer models as they get better and I am pretty sure I will also get a Chromebox as they become more available in the next 12 months.One more thing. My power supply....not a brick but a wonderful, light design, went bad. My call to customer service was smooth as silk and I had a new one in 3 days at no cost. Meanwhile, because of the micro usb design I was able to use other chargers while I waited.Good job HP. It moved me to order one of your new little tablets which I get today. All of this from an Apple Fanboy (still).

Reviews.Author: Pigearth
Reviews.Content: I love this thing.Returned a Samsung Chromebook today - really liked it but here are the reasons why I'm keeping (I think) this one:Way, way better screen - the smaller the screen size the more important making the most out of the native resolution is, particularly for those of us with old eyes.  Not nearly as sharp my first generation Nexus 7 but we're awhile out from seeing a super sharp Chromebook screen.  The matte black edges do a nice job of offsetting your screen, like a picture frame is used to focus the subject.  A nice psychological trick.More power out of the audio jack - whether driving headphones or running a mini stereo plug-to-rca to my receiver the Samsung is a little anemic.  At 10 the receiver had to be pushed hard to extract the music signal resulting in a bit too much distortion.  Regardless the HP is much more powerful, driving external speakers and its own very good internal speakers easily.The wrist rests don't bow - pressing on it inadvertently hard doesn't creak the chassis.  The entire structure is stiff.Ergonomics - little things like the slightly larger keys, their shape, the tighter build resulting in no loose keys, the beveled front edge and the even chassis temperature all make for a more pleasing experience.  And the trackpad.  It is extremely accurate, so much so if you're coming off a crappy generic Wintel laptop you have to recalibrate your senses.  This one means light pressure - the Samsung's was pretty good, I thought, until I used this.The charger - I thought the USB charger included wasn't going to be powerful.  Though I haven't done a time-tested depleted to full test yet it seems to charge quickly.  I'll append if I ever end up doing so.  Charging my Nexus 7 with it seemed to take about the same as with its native charger, but that has to do with the device throttling of the amperage.  One thing that's super stark is the weight and size difference between the Samsung's traditional brick-with-hair block and the sleekness of the HP's.  Though it's a solid, soldered connection from the USB cable to the brick you can daisy chain your other devices to the Chromebook.  All you'd need to do at night is plug your HP in, then carry one or two other USB cables to run off it.  Way, way nicer than separate bricks.  Battery life is less, I'd say maybe an hour or so.  That doesn't matter to me much - it's plugged in pretty much all the time.  An interesting design note is I'm pretty sure Google/HP designed the micro USB plug to fall out under certain pressure to avoid breakage, similar to Apple's magnetically attached cord.  The fit is tight but will drop out; having ruined a few cable/usb/audio jacks in my day, this is a good idea.Aesthetics - I thought I wouldn't like the white plastic designer-y aspect - wrong.  There's a complete lack of logos to anyone looking at it from the outside, which makes it mysteriously cool.  When the lid is open the 4 color light bar glows a bit; on the inside there's a very subtle "chrome" below the screen, finished in chrome of course.  Thank goodness there's no "powered by Celeron" stickers to peel off.  On the bottom there's a subtle "HP" then, in tiny font, "Made with Google".  Classy.  The blue trim, the only available at this time, isn't too fey and is a bit darker than the pictures, which give is a very slightly more manly feel, in case that matters to you.Connectivity - I thought this would be a lot worse than it is.  I was running an HDMI out of my Samsung and, while it worked, it wasn't ideal.  The jack was subject to a lot of strain while it was in my lap and the cable didn't seat properly all the time.  Over time it would get worse.  Of course I used this solution because the Samsung's screen just isn't sharp.  So far with the HP I haven't felt the need to hook it up to a monitor or HDTV.  That says a lot.  If you'd like to you'd need a Slimport ->HDMI/whatever dongle, the super expensive Analogix one isn't necessary.  -  Two USB 2.0 is better for me.  It allows you to daisy chain charging cables, is more widely compatible, and allows for dongles and adapters more easily.  No ethernet out means a $6 USB adapter.  No sD card reader?  No problem, another cheap dongle to the rescue.  You can get a small multi-card reader to pull in all your various mobile storage - sD, micro sD, Compact Flash, etc.  One way I haven't tried yet because Google just introduced this feature this weekend for ARM Chromebooks, is to plug your camera directly in and use Google+ Photos and their new Snapseed editor to transfer and manipulate your files.  If possible the necessity of a card reader is moot.  This is the case of "It's really nice the Hardware and Software Manufacturers are the same"._______________________________________________________________________What I don't like about it is it's slow.  For me.  That's all I want to say about that.The file manager - needs some polish.  There's no way to have two open so drag and drop between subfolders requires a lot of clicks in between.  The shortcut feature is ok but not fully functional and the way subfolders display twice in some cases a bit strange.  Also when copying into a folder with subfolders you can not place a single file NOT in a  sub- or root-folder.  Very annoying.  I've reported similar things to Google; if everyone were to do this the OS gets better, so I'd encourage everyone to do so:  [...]Also errors occur when you're copying large files from, say, an external drive to GDrive, whereas if you use the GDrive uploader they don't, so do that.I'm sure there's more but I'm hungry...----------------------------------------------------------------------The charge doesn't last that long, maybe 4.5 to 6hrs. at the outer limit.  No doubt the bright screen and the aforementioned powerful audio out suck a lot of juice and maybe the ARM processor isn't optimal for such, but a minor quibble.  Charging yesterday from 13% to full took about 4hrs. while doing a bunch of other things, including streaming video at times.  Turning it off, obviously, would result in a much faster charge.The OS is doing some weird things with syncing Gdrive to the local cache, huge files.  There is a way to delete them, nevertheless.  Also I looked at a publicly-available Google spreadsheet online, didn't download, and now it is persistently available as being viewable offline.  Very annoying and can't get rid of it.Google+ Photo app is still displaying incorrectly, rendering it unusable.While the base is very sturdy the screen is quite flexible, so I'd be careful putting it in a backpack with books on that side.  Adjoining the base would be fine.  Also the glossy white, while smudgy, doesn't really look as bad dirty as a piano black one.  Or a non-oleophobic smart phone in the sun.I was unsure about the one-sided outputs but can now see the wisdom of the layout.  You only have to worry about entanglements on that side rather than be swarmed by cords.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Chrome OS buggy, some apps not fully fleshed out.  But from experience I know the developers are working hard to improve the product on a daily basis.  It's only a matter of time.Had to return previous unit due to what I thought was a hardware problem.  Turns out it was a software problem (see above).Track pad observation:  new units are very sensitive and don't glide well.  Use it a bit, allow your finger (and french fry) oils permeate the track pad.  Much smoother tracking and two-finger scrolling will occur, trust me.Kit Kat 4.4 Android introduced today to streamline Android processes, Chrome referenced to be sped up.  Hopefully that means Chrome OS so we'll see the ARM not overwhelmed at times.  Hopefully.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------3 Nov 2013Unfortunately I don't have another one of these; serving streaming radio will cache so much data my Nexus 7 will eventually bog and stop playing.  With ChromeOS it will run forever without a glitch (knock wood) due to its streamlined nature.Speaking of music I found out the speakers are stereo, which is pretty apparent when you're at the unit typing.  Pretty cool.A potentially great, great feature I've been using a lot is the Google+ Photo Editor - really nice effects but the software needs a bit of work to display larger when doing fine detail work, plus the clone tool is a bit of a mystery.  It would sure be nice of someone built in layers functionality into it but really the multiple slider tools offer a lot of quick and moderately advanced fixes for photo sharing.  Of course if you don't use or like Google+ just download the edited pictures and upload them to Facebook, the machine makes quick work of that. Added:  I'm convinced the editing software does a heckuva lot, such as noise reduction in shadows, that I could never get in Photoshop 6.0 without a lot of manual work.  I'm regularly extracting good, usable photos from something that no one would look at twice.  Gotta say the editing algorithms are spot on and not heavy-handed so far.  But heavy-handed is there when you want it.If you do any video editing check out the Auto Awesome feature for it - it can do amazing things automagically, including adding music to sync with cuts.  There's a video out there the developer claims to have let the software do 90% of the work to the finished film.  Nice that you can use cloud storage for the file AND web servers and software for crunching the data.Google+'s, and Google's, privacy policy seems less invasive to me than Facebook's, though I may be wrong.Though the screen is pretty nice the size of the hp11 lends itself nicely as a Chromecast controller, meaning you can have your cake and eat it too.The black levels of the display are really nice, meaning you can keep the brightness down in a dimly-lit room and still see the typefaces easily due good contrast.Contrary to what I said earlier it IS possible to have two File Mangers open - just right click the icon to open a new window.  Wish there were more comprehensive documentation for the OS in one spot, rather than banging my head against the wall for rudimentary tasks or questions/answers.

Reviews.Title: Good stuff.
Reviews.Author: Coby
Reviews.Content: This is not the type of laptop one would choose if thee is looking for a laptop that's the "full package". But the Chromebook 11 is a great laptop nonetheless.My Chromebook 11 (the Cerulean/White theme) was bought in-store at Best Buy. The packaging was super cheap. Its practically cardboard. But it was pretty thick--its tape kept it together when I unboxed it.During unboxing, I encountered a few difficulties with the packaging, but that's a pro for the security measures Google took to secure the laptop in the box. On the top there's a little disposable card defining the different things you can do with the Chromebook (which is limited) in a few simple words. Below it is the Chromebook itself. Under the Chromebook is the charger. The cable is not detachable. There is a HP Chromebook 11 user manual in it as well if you need some help setting stuff up.When starting up the Chromebook 11, the setup process is pretty easy. Its even easier if you already have a gmail account. The password you use for your gmail account corresponds to the login area when powering on the computer. You can tweak most of the settings in the Chrome browser.After a little less than month of use, the Chromebook got all of my basic stuff done. The Chrome OS was super simple to use and get recognized to. I'll start with the OS itself.Operating SystemThe operating system was super simple to use even if you're coming from OS X, Windows 7 (specifically, because 8.1 is cancer), or Linux. The OS is like any other. It has a menu bar that contains apps that are web-based (explained later) and interchangeable and a "meh", but simple file browser for files in the computer. The "apps" button (similar to the Windows button on the bottom left) is awkward because it only browses through all your applications you've "installed". I wouldn't call it convenient to use as I would like to see it revamped to have some of the core apps or features you'd find in a typical button that's supposed to be in what I'd call a "home" button (for example, the files browser alternative to "my computer" on Windows). Its simple and it works, but I'd like to see improvements.The browser that is specifically used on the Chromebook is Google Chrome. Now this is what makes the Chromebook different. Many of the applications on the Chromebook are alternatives and "google-ified" versions of something like the Office Suite or Apple Suite. For example, presentations, documents, and spreadsheets apps are changed into stuff like Google Docs, Google Presentations, etc. On the creative suite, that's really empty honestly. I've used web-based video and GFX editors, and they aren't as good as stuff like iMovie, Windows Movie Maker, Photoshop, or Pixelmator. The Chromebook is not for those looking to get creative work done. But since this is Google, I am determined to see how they'll solve this or even if they'll solve this. Also, because these are web-based apps (and a few apps that can be installed for offline use), internet connection is really important when using the Chromebook. Its use pretty much relies on whether you have access or not.Other than that, the OS is simple and could have a lot more things, but what can you ask for an OS that's really just starting out.Hardware from my perspectiveI value candor. I don't really know what defines good specifications, but I do know a few basic concepts. But all I care about really hardware-wise is how rough or smooth the performance is and how it is under light and intense activities. Also hardware-wise, I will discuss the other things provided in the computer such as the light bar on the top, the webcam, the keyboard, and the trackpad. Then there will be a section dedicated to the overall design and I will conclude with the performance.Starting off with the lightbar, I don't see much use with it. The light bar is basically cool-looking Google branding. I assume you can program it, but I hear that you can only do that on a Chromebook Pixel. Moving on, we have the webcam up top. The webcam is pretty horrible honestly if you plan on doing some professional recordings. However what do you expect from a laptop that's this cheap? Webcam quality is definitely pretty "eh". Very slow webcam processing, and if you look at it as a camera, it's basically bad. Transferring to the keyboard and trackpad, I find that it is similar to the Apple keyboard, just losing just a small bit of required pressure. Its not the best for some users, but it definitely is better than some other keyboards on some laptops (*cough* surface *cough*). They keys are all recognizable, however since this is a web-based OS, the computer generally also should be web-based. There is no caps lock keys. It is replaced with the "search" key. On the top you have the "escape" button, and it seems like a strange layout, but you have the "back/forward" button, the "refresh button", the "widescreen" button, the "window" command (views all of the windows you have open in a layout much like the multi-tasking on iOS devices or the "f3" button for OS X), the "lower/raise brightness" buttons, the "mute, soften, and raise volume" buttons, and lastly the power button. It seems like a weird layout, but I find that they are useful at times and not so much. If only they used Apple's keyboard layout it'd be awesome (listing the button number and its default action when pressed, however still leaving the user the option to program the keys). The trackpad on the other hand isn't Mac trackpad quality, but its definitely still "average". When I use the trackpad, I feel that browsing around with the trackpad has a lot of stuttering. I know that this is not a performance problem because I found out that you have to be light on pressure. Make as if you are caressing the trackpad. When clicking the trackpad on the other hand, two-finger clicking is sometimes unresponsive and only responds as the user clicking with one finger. The actual clicking itself varies. I don't know if this is a defect with my device, but it just feels like the trackpad will break, and then another day it feels nice and sturdy. Overall its sort of neutral between being bad and being awesome.Secondly, I'd like to talk about the design because I really do like it. Obviously the Chromebook is not expandable really--the Chromebook is practically sewn together in plastic. This may be negative or positive depending on how you look at it. The design is still really nice though. There is a blue accent around the keyboard, and two large rectangular blue feet under the computer that sitll look nice. Other than the light bar, HP/Google branding,  and the feet, its practically a white-painted computer. There's no screws, no openings, no nothing other than the ports. Speaking of the ports (great segway, right?), there are no ports on the right side! This has already gotten me worried. The ports will all be found on the left of the machine. There is a standard 3.5mm headphone jack (no microphone jack), two USB ports (not sure if it is 2.0/3.0), and the charging port. That is it. This is very limited, and thus that is why I dislike that they didn't do much about this. Again, I wouldn't expect something like all of the display ports like HDMI, VGA, etc., but I wonder why they didn't have an SD card reader. As a amateur 13-year-old photographer, I would've appreciated the SD card reader but I still have to use my iMac to edit photos and such.Lastly, I'd like to discuss the performance. The Chromebook 11 from an amateur-at-specs' perspective is actually quite quick when getting light tasks done. When doing performance-heavy stuff like watching a YouTube video alone at 1080p, the video looks good (I don't want to review the display because it already looks good on the laptop), however it tends to stutter. Watching videos at 720p on the other hand is pretty nice and although some quality is sacrificed, it still gives me a lot less stuttering. I also did some interacting on the web on a few websites like Kongregate. I find that the Chromebook 11 didn't fair that well on heavy websites like that. Not something the Chromebook is too great in, however it is still usable. I could go on, but that last website will pretty much wrap up all of the other applications one might use on a Chromebook.Generally, Chromebooks are new and they're off to a decent start. I like the computer for its price/performance ratio. I would pay $50 more for a computer as good as this on a Windows platform. I would definitely recommend the Chromebook to anyone just wanting to get light stuff done or browse the web. I wouldn't recommend it to professionals in most departments, however some of the alternatives on the Chrome OS like Google Docs is something you should still try and see if you like. There's just a few things that Google could do to improve this computer and sell it at a relatively similar price.

Reviews.Title: STUDENT REVIEW
Reviews.Author: Bacon
Reviews.Content: This is the best Chromebook yet! I recently got this from the Google Play store. I previously had the Samsung Chromebook 11 which was a good, however, this Chromebook is great and well worth the 30 dollars more. They may have the same internals and the speed is the same and the battery life. For 30 dollars more you get a brighter, more colorful, IPS Screen. The IPS screen has a vastly better viewing angle then the LCD screen on the Samsung. You will notice the screen quality difference immediately if you had previously had the Samsung. Also for 30 dollars more you get a way better external casing. If you have ever seen the older White Unibody Macbook's. This is almost exactly the same build but thinner due to no CD/DVD drive. It is built quite a bit better then the Samsung and also looks way more stylized. The Trackpad is better then the slightly jumpy Samsung Trackpad. I haven't noticed any real battery life differences between the better screened HP over the Samsung. Overall, if you are looking to buy the Samsung Chromebook I would highly recommend this HP over the Samsung. As I haven't had the other Chromebooks I can't compare those, though, I have seen them at this one is at least the best looking that I know of other then the Chromebook Pixel which is 1200 dollars and does the same things. You do lose the USB 3.0 and the HDMI out slots with the HP however, but unless you absolutely need to have those get the HP. I think part of the reason it is better then the Samsung is that the HP one is designed specifically by Google just like their 1200 dollar Chromebook Pixel was. I use the computer as a student in college and can say that you can do anything that you need with this computer when you are in school and don't have to pay for word processing or a expensive computer. This is a very nice computer. I will say this though. Do not get the Google designed cases for this Chromebook. They are 49.99 and are not nearly as good as others 11 inch cases. I would highly recommend getting the Incase Terra 11 inch zip up case off of Amazon for 20-25 dollars. It fits perfect and is very nice. In conclusion, if you want a nice computer and case for 300 dollars total and are a student or need only word processing and internet browsing and videos online then this is the computer you want and if you want a nice case for it, then get the Incase Terra 11 off Amazon as well.

Reviews.Title: I wish I liked it more...
Reviews.Author: martrom
Reviews.Content: The form factor is great, and the screen is excellent (the best of any Chromebooks I've tested).  The keyboard is sturdy and the touchpad good enough (a lot better than most laptops I've used).  Basically, I wish I could use this as a barebones laptop for traveling, one that I wouldn't have to worry much about due to its price point.Unfortunately, with more than about 4 tabs open, scrolling and switching windows has noticeable lag.  You won't however have any trouble watching Netflix, Hulu or HD Youtube videos -- just don't expect it to respond quickly if you are a heavy multitasker.  Although I purchased with the expectation that a Chromebook is "just a browser", for me the slowness is a dealbreaker (side note: I installed XFCE and some programs such as Firefox, Gimp, and LibreOffice using Crouton on this notebook, and they all ran surprisingly ok).If you could combine the Acer guts with the HP screen/form, it'd probably be the perfect Chromebook.  As the lineup stands this year, all of them still fall a bit short of what I feel is worth the expense.  The Samsung, with a worse screen, can be gotten for $200, but it's as slow as this HP (which is too slow).  The Acer C720 is speedy and also a nice looking machine, but the screen has limited viewing angles.The 1st generation of Chromebooks was interesting, this 2nd generation is compelling, but I think it'll be another refresh of hardware before I'm happy to spend $250-$300 on one.

Reviews.Title: Best Built Budget Chromebook But Already Outdated
Reviews.Author: BKarno
Reviews.Content: We have 4 Chromebooks in our family.  The latest Samsung model, an Acer C720 4GB and C720 2GB, and this HP Chromebook 11.  The HP is tops in build quality, sound, and keyboard, and the IPS screen dominates the other current offering's TN panels.  However, it's performance is nowhere near the standard being set by the Haswell chipped models.  So why would you buy this over the others?The build quality is really good compared to the other Chromebooks.  Very solid body; although I wish the display / lid was a bit more rigid and the finish not so glossy (really shows fingerprints).  Excellent keyboard.  None of the other Chromebooks we own is as nice to type on. The Samsung has nice keys, but these are much better; nice size / spacing and very quiet.  Excellent speakers.  If you rely on on-board sound you will really enjoy the performance of the HP's top firing, under keyboard speakers.  And of course, the display.  The IPS screen is clear and bright, the colors are so much more natural than the Samsung or the Acers, and the viewing angles are stellar as well.  Only the $1300 Pixel has better screen in a Chromebook.  If you can live with the lower performance of this Chromebook you will certianly be satisfied with the machine as a whole.  As long as you aren't opening tons of tabs at the same time it should work well.  My daughter uses this HP at college and she really loves it.  She notes that it streams Netflix and Hulu Plus really good for her, and that using Google Drive/Document and her cloud printer has worked really well.  The only complaint she has is with the charge times, and I have noticed this too.  Where many have praised the ability to charge with any Micro USB wire, charging is slow.  Even with the original charger (the recalled model that came with it) the charging was not as fast as the the Acers or the Samsung.  And if you try to charge this with the charger supplied with your smart phone it will take an even longer time and you will not be able to charge while you use it (the battery will still drain).Some additional observations.  The lack of an SD card slot, and no USB 3 may be an issue for some, and no HDMI makes extending the screen a bit more difficult.  Yes the Micro USB is Slim Port capable, but you can't charge and extend the screen at the same time.  The 16GB drive is small, but if you have transitioned to working in the cloud this shouldn't be an issue.  Still, even with a 100GB Google Drive account, I swapped out the SSD in my C720 for a 128GB unit and ended up with over 100 GB of local drive space.  As for the trackpad.  I really like the size and feel of it, but it can be a little jumpy sometimes.  Still it is generally smooth, quiet, and the clicker works well.  The Bluetooth works good with my Bose Soundlink Mini, and I have even hooked up my Nuforce Icon DAC via USB.  The Chromebooks all recognize the DAC and it sounds great with music played through Google Play.I give it 4 stars for the build, stellar screen, and cost to value.  The speed is adequate, but it lags with a lot of websites; Facebook being the one I notice the most.  My ideal Chromebook would have the screen, sound, and keyboard of the HP 11 with the performance of the Haswell machines.  One should also consider that with the popularity of the Chromebooks growing, additional manufacturers like Dell getting into the game, and the certainty that there will be a whole new crop of new and improved machines coming in the very near future, this machine may be outdated sooner than later.  Still, it is an excellent Chromebook.

Reviews.Title: Good for my purposes
Reviews.Author: Terence
Reviews.Content: I really enjoy this chromebook1. Easily to place on your lap when your watching tv and want to do some work2. Have read complaints about it being slow. Sure, if you're planning to play high graphics games or download tons of movies, don't buy this computer. If you want a work horse and do everything in the cloud. No problemo.3. Cool color and very very lightNo complaints!

Reviews.Title: Just as I expected
Reviews.Author: Darek
Reviews.Content: Got the package very fast, was very pleased with that. The battery life could be a bit better and the screen is very glossy but other than that its a great laptop. The speakers are loud and it looks great, it has everything that I need. Would recommend 100%

Reviews.Title: Get It.
Reviews.Author: Patrick Brock
Reviews.Content: I was not totally in the market for a new laptop, but had been looking as my battery on my HP Pavillion would not hold a charge for more than a few minutes and I had been wanting to get a tablet for browsing while lounging around the house. My friend told me about the Chromebooks and at first I thought no way it's that good. After a few days worth of research, I snagged a Chromebook 11. It does absolutely everything that I previously used my laptop for. Youtube, Netflix, Hulu, internet, google docs (word processing) and it does it all faster. The boot time on this thing is amazing. Battery life is pretty amazing too for everything I put it through. I currently am Chromecasting youtube videos to my tv, have five tabs open in my browser and typing this review. Been off charger for about three hours and have 3h 40m remaining. It's simple, easy to use and navigate, just sign in to google and you're off and running.

Reviews.Title: Worth the extra cost from the Samsung or Acer
Reviews.Author: StudentK
Reviews.Content: I had a Samsung Chromebook for about a month before the screen cracked without reason (I kept it in a case at all times and it hadn't suffered any sort of trauma).  I was able to pick up the HP Chromebook 11 instead when I replaced the Samsung and so far I've been much happier with the choice.  While the HP does run a bit more in cost, it is worth it in my opinion because the HP is much sturdier and a better looking design than the Samsung.  The multi-touch pad is great and very easy to use.  The AC adapter is also much smaller than on the Samsung model and doesn't have the heavy awkward power brick sometimes seen on other laptop models.  That being said, the micro USB connection point seems like it might be a bit flimsy after a lot of use, but as I have only had the laptop for a short time, it seems to be working great so far.If you have the extra cash, I would absolutely recommend picking up the HP Chromebook over the Samsung or Acer models!

Reviews.Title: Great but..
Reviews.Author: antoinette
Reviews.Content: I really love the laptop. It moves so fast and it's really good for what I need it for. Even though you need the internet to do a lot unless you download some offline apps, I still think it's great. The only thing I suggest is that they keep fixing the problems with the chargers. Mine won't charge and I haven't even had it for a month. I don't know if it's the charger port or the actual charger but the google chrome team is very helpful in finding out what the problem might be.

Reviews.Title: Adorable!
Reviews.Author: AC
Reviews.Content: Pros:This laptop is cute and small.Awesome screen, Keyboard is soft and quiet.Chrome OS is very organized and protected!Great for basic use, first timers, or kids.Cons:If you are big on itunes music/etc. this laptop is not for you.If you like to download music, games, movies, file extension programs, or etc. Chrome OS will not allow it.

Reviews.Title: Perfect machine for a casual user.
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I got my Chromebook 11 yesterday morning. Opened it up, plugged it in, logged into to Google and voila! Just like that I was good to go. I love the size. It's light, thin, and will easily fit in my work bag (no more lugging around an extra bag with the laptop in it). The sound quality is awesome. Listening to music on it is a pleasure. The display is awesome is well - crystal clear and sharp. It charged up quickly. I love that I can use the brick-charger to charge it up quickly, but that my phone charger will work with it as well for overnight charging. When I plugged that one in, it said that it was "connected to a low-power charger, and would not charge while the machine is in use. No big deal, my phone charges overnight as well, and if you're house is anything like ours you always have about 5 extra phone chargers lying around.In no way am I a "power-user".. I use my laptop for email, surfing online, and listening to music. This is exactly what I need - no more, no less. I couldn't be happier with my purchase!

Reviews.Title: Satisfied customer
Reviews.Author: Alain Agenor
Reviews.Content: I bought my Chromebook with the intention of possibly selling it in a month or so, as I am in between Macbooks. I recently sold my 11 inch air so I can get a 13" pro, for more satisfying movie watching experiences. I knew 30 minutes in, that I am going to keep this Chromebook. It's functionality is minimal, as everything is done through the chrome browser, which I love. There's no need to have several programs open, when you can surf the web, type up a document, check your email and keep up with sports scores, news and updates all from one program. The screen is absolutely beautiful and I can type on this keyboard all day. The sound quality is excellent and the boot speed is impressive to say the least. My only disappointments are how hard it is change audio tracks on movies with different audio tracks (which I still havent figured out, but I know i will), it was a bit slow, out the box and, though there's a keyboard shortcut for it, there's no caps lock button. WHATS UP WITH THAT!? I had to hold down shift to write that. Here in america, I need instant gratification. What kind of third world chump must I look like, having to hold down shift to write in all caps!?!? All in all, I do love my Chromebook. and I will probably keep it for traveling after I get my Macbook Pro

Reviews.Title: Appropriate trade-off's for this price point
Reviews.Author: A. Mindy
Reviews.Content: What it's not: Lightening fast, Full-featured Windows/Mac operating system, All-day battery lifeWhat it is: Great screen, Great keyboard, Great aesthetic design, Great sound, Moderate performance, No fanI knew all that going in.  Do your homework before buying a Chromebook.  Assuming you are willing to forego the full-feature of a traditional operating system--and I'm not going into those trade-off's here--then you are down to choosing which Chromebook you want.  All Chromebooks are relatively cheap, and therefore come with their own trade-off's.  I suggest you ignore any review of this or any Chromebook that rips on Chrome itself--there are plenty of other ways to get information on Chrome than Amazon reviews if you are unsure.I picked this one because I knew I cared more about how the screen looks and how it sounds than whether web sites take a few less seconds to load or whether I can have 20 tabs open.  I almost exclusively browse the web and watch YouTube videos on it.  Browsing will have upwards of 5 tabs before I lose track of what's going on.  It is perfectly serviceable for that level of activity.  For browsing, it's news sites, Gmail, Calendar, Keep, Drive--all Google properties--and it does just fine.  Not lightening quick by a long shot, but plenty fast when I know the screen/keyboard/sound combination helps me to enjoy the content.  And make no mistake, this particular Chromebook is more about content consumption than creation.  That said, it can and does do both.The visual design--no screws, no fan ports, simple white with blue accents--and the lack of a fan are huge X factors for me.  That I can sit in a quiet room and not add any noise like a tablet is great!  The visual appeal of a simple white (some would say Macbook knockoff) case is something you either care about or do not.  It's not make or break for me, but adds to likeability of the device post-purchase.  Small things like how the black bezel frames the screen make the whole package visually appealing.Be clear--if speed is of critical importance to you and any hiccup or delay will affect your enjoyment.......then this isn't the device for you!!!  There are better choices for raw speed with their own sets of trade-offs available.I only occasionally wish for (and would be willing to pay a little more $$ for) longer battery life and/or a slightly faster CPU in that order.  At this price point, I accept the trade-offs made and am extremely happy with the device.

Reviews.Title: Great machine for access to Google Services and web browsing.
Reviews.Author: Eric Korhonen
Reviews.Content: I purchased the Chromebook to try it out and see if it was any use to me. I have had a chrome book in the past and ended up selling it as it did no really meet my needs. What I was looking for was a light simple laptop that could connect to the internet for web browsing email etc nothing too complex that I could use when I was away from my home/office. I wanted something that was about the size of a iPad 2 with keyboard. I do use a iPad and like it but I wanted a better web browsing experience. I have been using the Chromebook 11now for a few weeks and I like it. Many reviews that I have seen criticise the machine for being underpowered or complaining that a chromebook can't do what a "regular" laptop can do. I think the Chromebook 11 is not trying to be a "regular" laptop but a chromebook which is to say a web browser with a keyboard that easily accesses Google services and any website and being very light and portable. I think it does this very well.  The screen is very nice has very good brightness and looks very crisp. The keyboard is very nice to use.
