I like that the machine can be charged from via a micro usb connector and does last all day for me travelling around. The machine is also very nice to hold and loos good. I carry it in a satchel with my iPad Air and it is very easy to carry around.  I like Chromeos quite a lot as it is very simple (basically just a web browser nothing more) and provides very easy access to Google services. If you don't use those buy something else. If you do this is a great machine.

Reviews.Title: Great as long as you know its limitations
Reviews.Author: Lon J. Seidman "lon@ lon.tv"
Reviews.Content: // To view this video download Flash Player (version 9.0.115 or higher)'); } } catch(err) { fp_resizePlayerSpace('cv_mo3472F6Z3KGD6A', 0, 0); } return false; } function _cv_mo3472F6Z3KGD6AloadSwf(movieID, playerVersion) { var swfLocation = "http://g-ecx.images-amazon.com/images/G/01/am3/20120510035744301/AMPlayer._V148501545_.swf"; logTag.type = "text/javascript"; logTag.src = "/gp/customer-media/du/log.html?ie=UTF8&p=CustomerImage&s=CustomerVideoPlay"; head[0].appendChild(logTag); } if (cv_mo3472F6Z3KGD6AcurrentClick) { return cv_mo3472F6Z3KGD6AcurrentClick(); } } } Length:: 9:48 MinsThis is an exceptionally well built computer for the price. The keyboard is fantastic, the trackpad is decent, and the display is just as good as the one on my 11" Macbook Air. So what's the trade off? A very limited operating system that needs to be connected to the Internet all the time in order to be useful.Chromebooks are computers that boot up to Google's ChromeOS - which itself is pretty much just a Chrome web browser. Google has built a nice eco system around it with quite a large catalog of HTML 5 apps that run inside Chrome on nearly all platforms. The Chromebook will sync itself to your other chrome installations, meaning that every extension and bookmark will be right where it is on your other devices.The problem is that the Chromebook becomes significantly less useful when it's offline. Documents are mostly inaccessible and apps that aren't expressly written to run offline in the browser won't load. The Chromebook 11 lacks an internal cellular modem so it will need to be within range of a WiFi access point (or a cellular hotspot) in order for it to work outside of a home or office. I did find that Google hid "quickoffice," an app that allows offline document editing, but I was only able to get it working if I had previously downloaded a compatible document to the machine first.Under the hood the Chromebook 11 has what is essentially a tablet or smartphone processor. It works fairly well but it isn't as snappy as a PC or modern tablet might be. YouTube videos stutter a bit when loading and text sometimes lags behind key presses when working on a document.So who's this for? It's a great kids machine provided they'll have constant and reliable access to the network. Since the documents are stored in the Google cloud there's little chance of losing anything due to a damaged or stolen device. Also those who are considering dumping their PC's for a tablet might want to consider this instead as it's more useful as a productivity device - provided they don't mind living in Google's cloud.

Reviews.Title: Cannot recommend until Google & HP resolve the power system design issues ...
Reviews.Author: Ron Musselman
Reviews.Content: Traded in the Samsung version when the HP was released because the design is far superior to the Samsung, as is the screen. The viewing angles on the Samsung were poor, the HP's are very good.This machine feels like a nicer, lighter version of the white, unibody MacBook from 2010. Might be a strange way to describe it but the laptop feels "friendly" in your hand - very smooth plastic with rounded edges.The Chrome OS is the same regardless of hardware so the HP is just as easy to use as all others. I really like that the system is ready to go and personalized automatically the first time I log in. All systems should work this way.Unfortunately, my experience has gone downhill rapidly. First, I had to wait for a replacement charger when the original was reported as defective. Google and HP handled that very poorly. Had it not been for media coverage I never would have known about the problem. Once I did know there was no communication from either company. When I finally received the new charger the Chromebook immediately displayed a graphical system message asking me if my charger looked like the new version. That was a nice touch and something that should have happened the moment Google and HP realized there was a problem.The new charger seemed to work well until 2 days ago. The system will not power on or charge. The charging light doesn't even come on. I've tried all the suggested troubleshooting steps to no avail - waiting for Google to respond to a service ticket now.Although the laptop looks very nice I can't rate the system more than a 2. Originally I would have rated it a 5, now I just want a refund. Unfortunately, I bought the system at Best Buy 2 months ago so it can't be returned.

Reviews.Title: Charging is a double edged sword
Reviews.Author: Nicholas Moore
Reviews.Content: Because there are so many reviews pertaining to the usage of this device I wanted to discuss charging the device via USB. Not many people talk about charging it because they assume that any USB port will charge it. Sadly, this assumption is false and below I will elaborate.The Chromebook 11 will charge from any USB port without issue but it may not provide 100% of the power needed to keep the laptop charged while it is in use. On virtually every charger, other than the stock charger, the UI will report that you are using a "low power charger".  The reason for this is not because the charger cannot supply up to 3A, in this battery it actually can. But it depends more on the voltage supplied.The stock charger provides 5.25 vDC with a maximum current rating of 3A. Virtually every charger designed for microUSB devices only supplies ~5.0 vDC.  By not having the 0.25 vDC the chromebook devices will not pull full at full capacity. Instead it is rate limited at some rate I have not been able to determine. I believe it to be somewhere between 700ma and 1.2A. My guess at their reasoning behind this is so that the chromebook does not try to overdraw the charging source when it detects that the voltage is below 5.25 vDC and an assumption is made that if it detects 5.25vDC, it can draw at 3A.I originally purchased this chromebook because I really liked that it could be charged by any USB port and my intentions were to buy one of those 12,000mAh extended life batteries to triple the life of the device. Even though it will charge it at a reduced rate I cannot prevent myself from rating this device with 5 stars because the compromises are well worth the flexibility. I just wanted others to understand that until someone comes out with a 5.25 vDC charger we're stuck with the original charger; not even those 36w car chargers will suffice. I really hope a manufacturer out there realizes this and designs a 12v car charger and a battery which can supply the full voltage at the appropriate amperage for this device.Hope this helps

Reviews.Title: Really happy with the design and build quality of this little machine.  It comes with me everywhere!
Reviews.Author: Brian McL
Reviews.Content: I picked this up as soon as it went up for sale.  I had a CR-48 and a Acer C710 chromebook i upgraded to 4gb of memory, but the battery doesn't last past 4 hours on that.This HP has been amazing so far, and I've only taken it on 2 trips.  I've gotten 5-6 hours consistently out of it while online.  It is really nice to have a small charger I can use for it too.  It does not have a huge brick, but a cell phone size micro usb charger.  It does put out more power than a regular micro usb charger, but in a pinch you can charge it with a cell phone charger.Pros:- It plays 1080 youtube no problem(the CR-48 couldn't)- It lasts 5-6 hours average, I've gotten 6.5 a few times too if i turn brightness down a bit.- Keyboard is very very nice to type on for extended periods.- 6-8 second boot time is AMAZING- NO moving parts- Handles 10-15 tabs no problem, I've pushed it to 30 tabs, but there is a little bit of lag between switching tabs- The screen is amazing to look at.  My girlfriend couldn't believe it when she first held it and looked at it- It weighs next to nothing (2.1 lbs?) Compared to the C710 this weighs so much less.Cons:- Doesn't last 9 hours like some of the larger chromebooks- If you charge it from a regular USB charger, it can take all day to charge

Reviews.Title: Slim, lightweight, and more powerful than it's specs suggest.
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I'm now two weeks into my ownership of the 11 and I couldn't be happier with it.Anyone I have shown the 11 to is amazed that the CPU is effectively a phone processor. The only time I ever really make it work hard is when first starting up the browser (I have 5 pinned tabs) for the first time after a fresh boot, which rarely ever happens. Navigation and scrolling are just as fast and smooth as you would expect from a regular laptop, let alone something like this.Cold start is less than 20 seconds to desktop, including typing in my password. Login appears in ~10 seconds.Resume from sleep is practically instantaneous and the login prompt appears before I can get my hands set on the keyboard.Battery life is fantastic considering that 2,300mAh is smaller than the battery in my Galaxy S4. I don't know that I can get the advertised 6 hours of use because of my usage patterns, but I easily get 4 hours without issue. And recharging with the 3A USB charger is extremely fast, so downtime is minimal.Speaking of, the USB charging is wonderful and I want ALL laptop manufacturers to get on this train if possible. Being able to at least trickle charge anywhere I can find a USB port is awesome (I usually use the charger from my S4 when I'm not at home), and anything over 2A should be enough to at least keep the battery level constant under normal usage.PROSThin, compact, lightweight, USB charging, very nice (IPS) screen, fanless.CONSStruggles loading large amounts of content (but recovers quickly), doesn't make me coffee in the morning or was my car on Saturdays (working on both of those)

Reviews.Title: Fantastic Student Laptop replacement
Reviews.Author: Kevin M. Hubbard
Reviews.Content: I purchased the black version of the Chromebook 11 for my daughter in high school. I was tired of administering Windows laptops and wanted something that she could use both for writing papers ( Google Docs ) and internet access to school websites and online text books and not have to worry about games, viruses, etc. She always has WiFi access at home, school and the local library, so a Chromebook made a lot of sense. The small size size 12" x 8" x 0.7" and weight ~2 lbs makes it easy to lug around in a backpack all day.About the Charger:The charger is a 3A micro-USB charger that is about the size of a cell phone charger (much smaller than a bulky laptop charger). Huge bonus is this charger can also charge her Galaxy Android phone, so she only needs to carry around a single charger - and its small. A regular 1A or 2A micro-USB cell phone charger will also slowly charge the battery if the Chromebook is off, or dramatically slow down the battery discharge of an already charged battery if the Chromebook is on. If the battery is completely dead and you only have a 1A or 2A charger you need to keep the Chromebook off until the battery gets a bit of a charge. Confusing - I know. My only concern is that micro-USB connectors in general are rather fragile compared to large "barrel" jacks. The cable is connected directly to the wall adapter ( instead of a USB-A connector ), so if the micro-USB connector breaks ( it happens ), you must buy another $20 3A charger from Google or HP instead of just replacing a $5 USB cable. Standard USB cables won't handle 3 amps, so I get why its soldered directly, still its unfortunate. Only the special HP 3A chargers will completely power the Chromebook and charge the battery at the same time, so you really need at least one. I think having all portable electronic devices charge from the same micro-USB connector is a fantastic move for the industry though. Are you listening Tim?Other features: The screen and keyboard are fantastic. The CPU is fast and perfectly adequate for Google Docs and web surfing. This isn't truly a laptop replacement, more of a tablet with built in keyboard and minimal local storage. That said, it is much faster ( and smaller ) than the MSI U100 Intel Atom Netbook that it replaced.Cloud Printing is simple enough assuming you have a Windows PC connected to printers, you just enable cloud printing through the Chrome browser on the PC and then your Chromebook ( and all your devices with Google accounts ) will have access to those printers - Very slick Google. Haven't tried Google Docs offline mode yet, but as far as I know it should work to write documents even outside of WiFi range.I definitely plan to purchase more Chromebooks in the future as I think it is quite practical for a large household to have a single Windows PC supplemented by tablets and Chromebooks. I highly recommend the black Chromebook 11 for basic web access and Google Docs.

Reviews.Title: The best new chromebook for people who aren't power users
Reviews.Author: Anthony Pirtle
Reviews.Content: I won't bother explaining what a chromebook is, its advantages and limitations, since there are thousands of web pages out there that do so. Assuming you do want a chromebook, this is a great choice.Actually, I should stipulate that if you are a power browser, that is someone who uses more than half a dozen browser tabs or windows at once, you'd probably be happier with one of the new Haswell Celeron chromebooks like the Acer C720. I'm not a power user, and I owned Acer's previous chromebook model, and my biggest gripes were that it had a rubbish keyboard, terrible speakers, a dismal display, and its battery life was less than three hours (at least for me). When I saw the new chromebooks hitting the market and decided to upgrade, I had to choose between getting the new Acer, which slightly improved the processing speed and dramatically improved battery life over my current model, or this one, which only doubled the battery life and actually had less power, but was supposed to be a serious improvement in design and build quality.I chose the HP Chromebook 11, and I'm very pleased. The screen is gorgeous, the best you'll find on anything even twice as expensive as this device. It has true colors and great viewing angles. It's a glossy screen, so it's not as easy to see outside, but if that's not a concern for you, it destroys the new Acer model. The keyboard is similarly terrific. It's not just better than Acer's, it's actually a joy to type on. I have never used this nice of a keyboard on a budget laptop, and believe me, I've owned a fair number of budget laptops from all manner of companies. The speakers are my favorite feature. They are clear and powerful, far better than anything I've had on a laptop before, let alone a chromebook. The battery life is around six hours for me, and that's a big step up from the older Acer, though not as spectacular as the Acer C720, with its 8+ hours.Bottom line - if you want the most power and longevity in a new model chromebook, get the Acer C720. However, if you want adequate power and battery life combined with the very best display, keyboard, speakers, and overall design, this is the model you should buy.Update (12/24/13): These machines recently made headlines when the chargers were recalled because of a small number of reports involving overhearing, so I sent for a replacement and it was rapidly FedEx-ed to my door, along with return postage for my old charger and a $25 gift card for the Google Play store. I never even had a problem with my charger, but it was nice to see Google take care of the issue so quickly. The new charger is also more attractively designed than the old one, so that's a bonus.

Reviews.Title: Worked well until it stopped working ....
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I bought the chromebook 11 as a family computer mainly to help the kids with their online studies.  Everyone loved it at first.  The trackpad is weak and tends to jump around a bit which has really bothered my son, but I find it acceptable.  However, 2.5 months into owning it has stopped working.  At first it looked like a battery or charging issue, but now it's just dead.  Now I get to see how good HP's customer service is.Meanwhile, I am going to try the Acer.UPDATE:I just spent an hour on the hp website and on the phone trying to figure out how I can get my two month old non-working HP Chromebook serviced and have no results.  I cannot recommend buying this product.The Acer chromebook showed up and, first and foremost, it works.  It seems much better and more solid than the HP Chromebook.

Reviews.Title: It does what I need
Reviews.Author: Brandon S.
Reviews.Content: Browsing the internet, streaming music via Google Play, typing up notes for University - the HP Chromebook does what I need it to do, and at a very fair price (I got the Verizon LTE model for $199 on contract from Best Buy).Chromebooks are not meant to be your primary computer, rather a portable disposable computer - key word on disposable. This particular model loads pages rather slow, much slower than my iPad Air or iPhone 5s, so keep that in mind.If you're in the market for a full-featured PC this is not the computer for you. However, If you want a fun computer to take with you to campus, your local coffee shop or on the train, then this is the perfect computer for you.If you have any questions, feel free to reply to this review and I'll get back to you ASAP.

Reviews.Title: What a great little computer
Reviews.Author: Ol' Reg
Reviews.Content: I read ll the negative reviews. I'm sure every product has some detractors but I must say that I bought my Chromebook 11 to supplement my regular laptop and for traveling. The speaker system, which is under the keyboard, is surprisingly good.It linked up quickly to my router and every router I've accessed.  It's very lightweight, very fast and the battery life is fantastic. The screen is bright and sharp and the keyboard has nice feel. There are some keyboard shortcuts you need to learn to make it so shift-lock and delete (instead of just backspace) but that's incidental.It's NOT a replacement for a regular laptop. If you want storage, you only need to put an external HD like a WD Passport in the USB slot and you've got tons.If you just don't want to spend much on a small, full-featured laptop, you should probably be on the auction site and buy a new operating system as well.  This is a Chrome browser based machine, not Android, Windows or Apple. So far, viruses are not a concern with Chrome..Google Apps is a pretty good bunch of stuff to use. I hardly use any of them on this machine.I use it mostly for email and internet search and cannot imagine anyone finding it a less than perfect small browsing machine.Not long after I registered it, I got notice from Google or HP that the charger was to be replaced. They mailed out a new one and I continued to use the old one (they all get warm) until it arrived.I have not one negative comment to make. I knew what I was buying, knew it's shortcomings and knew its capabilities beforehand.I can only say that if one understands what one is getting they will not be disappointed with this gem.

Reviews.Title: Awesome!
Reviews.Author: Jill
Reviews.Content: We got this Chromebook for our teenage son and he fell in love with it right away!  Great product!  It arrived on time and the packaging is very nice too!

Reviews.Title: Love it
Reviews.Author: Marji
Reviews.Content: Love this computer, Its very slim and light weight.  I just wish it had the ability to print without another computer

Reviews.Title: This is amazing.
Reviews.Author: Raf  Vanheyst
Reviews.Content: First off all a very quick an splendit service and shipment. Great job! And a most beautiful design it is. The Chromebook ist an eye-catcher and works like the Samsung Chromebook, quick and easy. To bad the US-charger don't match here in Germany, so Ihad to buy a adapter. But at last it was a pleasure to buy in the US- amazonshop. Thanks for everything. Keep on the good work.

Reviews.Title: If you know what your getting with this, you'll be thrilled.  **Updated**
Reviews.Author: Jon K
Reviews.Content: As some have stated before, this is Chrome OS and not a full Windows PC.  That means no MS Office and the like.  So long as you understand that, you'll be very happy.  I personally like having a heavyweight desktop at home for the serious stuff and something small and portable for the road.Though I've never been an HP fan, this laptop delights.  The feel reminds me of the white MacBooks from a few years back.  The build is solid, the keys nicely spaced, and a responsive trackpad.  What is more important to me than any other though is the screen.  And this didn't disappoint.  Though the screen specs may not be something to write home to momma about, the display is crisp and bright with good viewing angles.  I've seen the other Chromebooks in person and non of them have a better screen (except the Google Pixel obviously).  The other displays seem dull and washed out.It's light, great screen, long battery, and simple to use.  Works great when traveling and going to client meetings.  I love it.**Update**I was initially thrilled with this Chromebook.  However after a few weeks of using it I have decided to return it.  I originally purchased this Chromebook last year when it was first released and it was fast and zippy and I didn't have any problems with it.  Then HP recalled them due to faulty chargers overheating.  Mine overheated alot.  So I sent it in for refund and anxiously awaited a fixed version to buy.  While the hardware appears to be the same, this new one I purchased is incredibly slow at everything.  Opening apps, surfing, you name it.  It also keeps either dropping my wifi connection regardless of the network I'm on and streams all data very slow even on a fast network.  I'm not saying everyone will have this problem, but I did.  It's definitely not the same Chromebook I initially purchased.  I would be interested in hearing if anyone else has these issues.

Reviews.Title: ChromeOS Portable with IPS screen
Reviews.Author: Kommisar
Reviews.Content: First time chromebook user here. Bought this product from another vendor because it was out of stock.  Up to this point I have used low end windows laptops. This laptop was surprisingly good compared to them. The screen is awesome. I have to say it again, the screen is awesome because of the large vertical viewing angles. Horizontal viewing angles are important if you are sharing your screen with someone is sitting next to you.  Vertical viewing angles are very very important for the quality of image that you see. I have previously been subject to cheap TN panels on the laptops I have used and these result in poor vertical viewing angles.  A poor vertical viewing angle means that I see the colors shift at the top and bottom of a screen no matter how I position the screen.  This color shift appears as if portions of the image are seen as if they are a photographic negative of the actual image. This laptop has a decent quality IPS panel which doesn't suffer from this problem.  It is fantastic to get accurate color top to bottom, no screen fiddling necessary. You see the screen as it was meant to be seen.  IMHO it's worth sacrificing a faster cpu and more ram for an IPS screen.  It's that good. The keyboard is nice as well.  It is a nice full size keyboard which means I can touch type on it at full speed.  In addition, it has useful keys in place of the function keys that are found on a typical windows keyboard.  For example, there are keys for expanding a browser window to full screen, going forward, backward and reloading a page.  I actually use these while browsing instead of hunting for a icon or menu item.I am a bit of a tinkerer and I like debian and I was able to install debian to run along side chrome os easily.  I booted into developer mode ("esc-refresh-power" and then at the warning screen "cntl-d"), logged into the system using my google credentials, downloaded crouton ([...]), opened a crosh shell (ctrl-alt-t), invoked a bash shell in the crosh shell ("shell") and then used the command "sudo sh -e ~/Downloads/crouton -r wheezy -n debian -t lxde" to install a nice debian lxde chroot. Note that booting into developer mode erases all user data so make sure any important files are saved somewhere else first.  A quick "sudo startlxde" in the bash shell booted the debian chroot.  From within chrome OS a quick cntl-alt-shift-forward (forward at the top of the keyboard, not the lower right) switches me to the debian chroot. Cntl-alt-shift-back switches back to chromeOS from the chroot. The chromeOS and the chroot share the Downloads folder so it is easy to use the same files from each OS environment. From inside this debian chroot I installed abiword, gnumeric, evince, hardinfo, and geany. I plan on checking out the google offline apps to see how they compare to my favorite debian apps.  Search the web for "ubuntu chromebook" and find the article on lifehacker or how-to-geek for more info on crouton, entering developer mode and chroots.UPDATE 3/13/14After a few months of use here are my findings.  Crouton and linux is not a practical solution for this machine or any chromebook for that matter.  First, there is no way to turn off the boot sequence that gives you a choice to go into developer mode.  You are only a space bar push away from the machine erasing any customizations and installations of crouton.  Also by using developer mode you disable one of the most compelling features of chromeos, the verified boot.  Now you could completely remove chromeos but this would require flashing the boot ROM with non-chromeos boot code.  I'm not sure if this particular model has an easy way to turn off the write protection on the boot ROM.  I also don't know if there is a boot ROM image that will work with this particular machine.  So to make a long story short, if you are primarly interested in linux, get a cheap windows machine and install linux.  There are too many comprises using crouton on a chromebook and installing a full blown linux is going to be PITA due to the need to reflash a boot ROM.

Reviews.Title: If you like the Samsung Chromebook, you'll like this one
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I'm not going to bother getting into the debate on whether a chromebook is a good choice versus a netbook, laptop, mac, whatever.  It's been done to death, and is a truly pointless debate.  If you're unsure, see if you can work with just a chrome browser, and chrome browser apps for a while, then ask yourself if you can work with that on the road, or even at home, or under certain conditions, and yes, it probably shouldn't be your sole computer.  Done.As to the machine:  I just got mine (by the way you can get in a couple days via the Google Play store if you don't want to wait for Amazon to get their stock) and it's pretty much the same weight and feel as the Samsung.  Keyboard is nice, sound emanates from under the keyboard as they say, and the feel of the device overall is actually a bit better than the Samsung.  The primary difference is the display -- it's brighter and "richer" than the Samsung.  This should come at some battery life cost, but I've found mine is still okay after 5 hours so far.I think the aesthetic quality will hold over time a bit better, if that matters to you. The "metal" look of the Samsung quickly scarred and looked pretty horrible after a few months use on my Samsung.  White plastic with trimactually looks fine with this device.  The feel of it is the nice feather-light feel you may know from the Samsung (or Mac Air), but with a bit more of a substantial feel to it.The construction seem well thought-out, and functionally, it does exactly what you would expect if you know Chromebooks.  I started it up, logged in, let it update, and other than adding my additional languages and setting a custom wallpaper, I can tell no difference, interface-wise, from my chromebook (which is exactly how it should be).  Wireless picked up quickly and easily.Not much else to say -- it is what a chromebook is (in my opinion, a good thing -- work with them exclusively now managing Linux, Windows, and Mac machines), and in my opinion, it's a very nice, lightweight chromebook with a good feel to it and a nice screen, especially for the price.  I think this machine should really be in the $300+ range.

Reviews.Title: My 4th and favorite Chromebook!
Reviews.Author: mike
Reviews.Content: As this is a review of the HP 11 and not Chrome OS, I'll avoid discussing 'software'. Needless to say, if it works in the Chrome web browser without additional software, it will work on a Chromebook.I've owned a Samsung Series 5 since they came out, a Series 550 when they came out and a Series 3 when they came out a year ago. Ive used a Chromebook as my main laptop for a half-year stretch, everything went fine, bought a MacBook to try, and now I'm back on Chromebooks. A week ago I bought an HP 11 in red from Google, here is my breakdown.Pros :- Screen. Amazing color clarity. Blacks are black, there is no light bleeding, no viewing angle issues, it's really impressive when compared to previous models.- Speakers are loud! Half volume is enough to fill my living room with sound. They do crackle if you turn them up too loud, but there is usually no need to.- Keyboard is *incredible*. Before this CB, the Series 5 had my favorite keyboard, this one is better yet. Springy and not too shallow, VERY quiet.- The build quality is what really blew me away about this CB. It's solid! Other Chromebooks, especially the 5 550, were prone to creaking, especially when you open them, this one is silent and extremely well built (or at least it feels that way). The plastic isn't cheap like on the Series 3 and 5, it doesn't flex.- It's silent. I couldn't imagine a better companion for class than this Chromebook. I actually hear 'phantom fan noise' every now and then, having used a MBA with a loud fan for so long, silent operation is great.- Battery life. Compared to my 3g Series 5, its WAY shorter (the 5 gets 8 hours), but compared to the 550 its about 2 hours longer. It's nearly identical to the Series 3. It's not super long, but not short at all. I can take it with me to class and not have to charge it if I work offline when taking notes (you can use Google Docs and Slides offline!!). Because it's charged with a micro usb, you can buy extended batteries designed for charging phones to extend the battery life, though I can't see needing that.- Price. $279 is REALLY hard to beat for the quality of this thing.- USB charging! I can unplug my Chromebook and plug in my phone to the same charger. My phone gets topped off before the Chromebook battery goes down even 5%, it's great not having to find a cable for my phone anymore.Cons :- The trackpad could be more accurate. It feels great, but the Series 3 and 550 both have glass coatings which made them wonderful to use. The HP 11 is similar to the Series 5, which is still great, but not as smooth or accurate.- Chrome OS is not fully optimized for ARM. This isn't a flaw with the Chromebook, it's Chrome OS. Until the Series 3 (released last year), Chrome OS has been on Intel chips. That's a solid 2+ years of development for x86/x64. In time though, Chrome OS will become better on ARM. My Series 5 still runs Chrome OS well (my girlfriend uses it every day), I imagine the Series 3 and HP 11 will run it well into the future also.I would have no problem recommending the HP 11 to anyone. Some will say "Get the Haswell one instead", and honestly, I've got a 550 with a Sandybridge Celeron and Ive used a C720 (which I shipped back for this one!), the difference is noticeable maybe 5% of the time. The other 95% of the time what I DO notice is the keyboard, speakers and display. Google and HP made the most-used parts of a Chromebook the best they could for the price and sacrificed a little performance for it, and personally, I prefer the small size and crazy-good build quality over small performance gains any day. If you are into comparing specs, maybe you're missing the point of using a Chromebook.edit: zRAM is enabled by default in Chrome OS now so 'enable swap' is no longer necessary. I do recommend disabling extensions you don't often use and installing Flash Control and AdBlock Plus to speed things up.

Reviews.Title: Disappointment
Reviews.Author: Qiangli H.
Reviews.Content: Bad charger that broke after not even a monthLaptop gets so slow that you cannot even move the mouse when two tabs are openCamera is terribleSupports no downloadable applicationsChrome store/play is useless, exception for some apps

Reviews.Title: For the money, not much else will beat it.
Reviews.Author: Kyle
Reviews.Content: I purchased this Chromebook as a gift for my girlfriend. She is a full-time student, nurse, and mom. We already have a 17" Lenovo laptop in the house, but it's a constant battle of "who needs the computer". I wanted to get her something that was not only portable and reliable, but would also suit her taste. Normally against my better judgement, the aesthetic of the HP 11 was a huge deciding factor for my purchase. I figured that at most, she'd have a few tabs open, maybe listen to a song on YouTube, and edit a paper in Office at any given time, so the fact that it wasn't a 'powerhouse' laptop wasn't really an issue.BUILD QUALITY:----------------------I searched high and low for reviews on build quality, screen quality, etc. I have to say that upon messing around with it today for about an hour or two, it has exceeded my expectations. The screen is absolutely beautiful. The clarity and range of color really is just amazing. I was worried that at 11", it would be a real pain to switch from the 17" screen I'm so used to. That was not the case at all. I'm 6'1" and I wouldn't say I've got big hands, but I'm a pretty big guy, and the HP 11 felt very comfortable on my lap. There was no "squinting" or straining to see the text on the screen as I feared there would be. Everything was absolutely crisp and clear. As far as the build quality, it feels very rigid. The plastic is very sturdy and the hinge is tight (I feel I need to point out that on any other >$300 laptop I've used, a squeaky or loose hinge is an absolute dealbreaker for me). If I could summarize the overall "feel" I get from the actual form of the laptop, it would be "Plastic Macbook". The keyboard and trackpad feel great.The speakers are actually built under the keyboard. They get very loud for a laptop. You won't be getting a lot of bass (It's actually almost non-existent), but the midrange and treble is there. For a $225 laptop, it's not getting much better. If you need the bass, there is always the headphone jack (audio was very full and pleasant from there with my headphones!)Oh, and this thing charges with a micro-USB. That is awesome. I have like seven of those things lying around my house, so it's good to know that even if I lose the laptop charger, I can still power on my Chromebook (albeit a bit more slowly)Overall, the HP 11 just feels right. It's great. I had my reservations with buying another HP having owned a Pavilion in the past (Eek. Hard drive failed, hinge creaking from day one, keys breaking off) so I was surprised to see that they seemingly hit it out of the park on this one. Time will tell, but the initial impression is great!PERFORMANCE:-----------------------Most people's main beef with this Chromebook is the performance. I'll be honest, I was worried before it arrived. I was wondering if I had just spent money on a pretty, but unusable laptop. As beautiful as the laptop is, I would have felt like an idiot if it was not even functional. The first thing I did when I got the laptop was open up Chrome (since you won't be doing much else?). I opened my Gmail, my Drive folder, a YouTube page, Facebook, and a Word document. I figured that rather than going on a mission to bog down the computer, I would use the computer as my girlfriend will use it. Talking to a friend on Facebook, writing a paper, listening to music, etc. With all of those tabs open, I only really experienced "stuttering" (specifically the YouTube audio) when trying to scroll too fast within a page or switch between tabs back to back to back.Under normal circumstances (i.e; not playing games, programming, and doing video editing at the same time), the laptop will be fine for anyone doing light to moderate browsing and work online. This would be a killer laptop for the non-techies in your life. My girlfriend isn't concerned with video editing/programming/rendering, and most people aren't. They're looking for a simple way to get online, check their email, do some office work. Most people don't need 8GB ram, 4.0 GHz processor, and 1TB hard drive.PROS:---------+ Great screen. Vivid, bright, detailed. It holds a candle to a Macbook's display.+ Very sturdy build. Doesn't feel cheap like most laptops in it's price range+ Stays cool and quiet (no fan!)+ ChromeOS is simple and intuitive. No start menus/control panels/preferences (the kind that scare grandma; there are options within the Chrome browser to customize your experience) to confuse you. It's very straightforward and presented within a very clean user interface.CONS:---------- The HP 11 does not pack a lot of horsepower. It's great for handling web surfing, document editing, video calls, and light YouTubing. You won't be doing heavy photo/video editing, gaming, or programming (unless you boot Ubuntu, but that's a whole different story), but chances are, you aren't looking at a Chromebook if you are doing any of those things.- Sound quality could be better. It's loud and clear, but it could benefit from some more low end.- ChromeOS does not support adding any programs such as iTunes, Photoshop, or VLC. You can get away with alternatives like Google Music and Pixlr Photo Editor.OVERALL:-------------This little thing is pretty cool. Hopefully it holds up over time. I know that software updates won't be an issue until 2018 (the year Google guaranteed it's support). If it does hold up, I see myself grabbing this over my 17" monster of a Lenovo laptop when I just want to hop online for a bit.Most of the gripes I have with it are things I knew getting into it. I know the ChromeOS in it's current state is a bit limited in what it can do. I knew that it wouldn't be a workhorse of a laptop. I knew that at it's price point, I'd sacrifice things like sound quality for screen quality and yadda-yadda-yadda. I think that's why I was pleasantly surprised when the screen was *that* nice and it was able to do more things at once than I thought it could.Solid purchase; highly recommended!

Reviews.Title: Suggested
Reviews.Author: Ryan Mannion
Reviews.Content: Bought this for my girlfriend and she couldn't be happier. I will probably get a chrome book for my next computer and this hp is definitely the front runner.

Reviews.Title: 2nd Chromebook
Reviews.Author: Austinhorn
Reviews.Content: We love our chromebooks & this would be the perfect web surfing device if it just had a touchscreen like my Acer c720p.  This little chromebook looks much more expensive than it is & makes a great 2nd computer. The IPS screen on it coupled with the outstanding keyboard & good trackpad is a step above most other chromebooks I've tried. However, I prefer my Acer slightly to this one due to the lack of a touchscreen.  I use a smartphone & am use to tablets so that may matter to me more than most people.  This is still a great device at the price.Update - I've had a lot of keyboard problems with the Acer c720p in the form of some keys not working or only working now & then. This thing though,works great & I love the ability to charge this thing with my smart phone charger. NICE. As soon as Acer fixes or replaces my C720p I plan to sell it. I now have a high end Chromebook Pixel as my primary Chrome device (it is world class), but because I like this thing so much, I plan to keep it as a backup. Great screen, great keyboard & touchpad, & really attractive form factor.  If only it were a little more powerful with a faster chip. Still it is a great device to have on your lap as you watch tv, movies or YouTube. Highly recommended.Update - May 2014 I've been using both Chromebooks a lot since my last update & as a result of OS updates to Chrome all of my keyboard related issues with the Acer c720p have dissappeared. Why I don't know but they have. At the same time, I still love this thing for it's portability, looks, & keyboard. I find it great for texting & e-mails. However anything much beyond that & this thing slows down quickly or stops. Watching movies or videos on-line is pretty much a no go on this device. I've never managed to watch a two hour movie on this but if I did, my guess is it would take 4-5 hours & the battery would be long gone before that happened. The IPS screen is still great, the keyboard is pretty good, but I"m now finding the track pad pretty weak. If this thing had a Haswell processor & a bit better touchpad, & as long as I'm wishing, a touch screen, then it would be an Ideal Chromebook. But now that I've had time to use it for a while, I plan to sell it or downstream it to one of my kids.  The processor makes it's ongoing use just too frustrating. Get a Dell or a Acer c720p if you like a touchscreen as much as I do.  If you can, I might wait for the summer to see how the newer models turn out. Faster processors & more ram have to help the Chrome OS experience.

Reviews.Title: Great computer at a great price!
Reviews.Author: Kelsey Gibbons
Reviews.Content: After having problems with my 4+  year old computer, I needed to upgrade, and wanted something that would be good for watching TV, working online or doing word processing. It has great graphics, great sound and is incredibly portable and light.Can't go wrong at this price, either. Very impressed, and would highly recommend.

Reviews.Title: Chromebook
Reviews.Author: Jo Wolf
Reviews.Content: I am not good with technology and this is just what I wanted. It's simple and easy to use. I can watch netflix on it and browse the internet quickly. I am very happy with it! The only thing is I wish it had a disc drive but it's not a laptop per say so that's understandable. Overall I am so very pleased with my purchase

Reviews.Title: Great value
Reviews.Author: Rachel Stubbs
Reviews.Content: This is an awesome computer. It is fast and clear and doesn't get bogged down. It is perfect for school or home.

Reviews.Title: Super fast start up!! Super light!! Super happy
Reviews.Author: Steven
Reviews.Content: This is by far the best investment that i have made. I watch alot of movies online and this lightweight chromebook is perfect for "entertainment". Not so good when it comes to having to save and print as the process is so confusing, but overall if you are a person that jumps on youtube for some music or to shop online than this is for you.

Reviews.Title: Awesome
Reviews.Author: Denise
Reviews.Content: Girl cried her eyes out when she open her present. Thanks Amazon for a great job pulling this one off. She loved it.

Reviews.Title: i love this thing!!
Reviews.Author: jott
Reviews.Content: Chromebook 11 by HP is amazing!  its so fast--  I just wanted something to browse around on the internet-- buy stuff from amazon- check emails, watch google play through chromecast--- This is perfect for that.  There's even a Chrome remote desktop app i have on my work computer, so i can check my work outlook emails and log into everything i have at work from the chromebook at home or on the road.  I love how fast it comes on when opened.  Also, HP fixed the charging wire, and gave everyone who had one $25 in google play bucks.  Sweet deal.

Reviews.Title: Really nice browsing machine!
Reviews.Author: Mr Matthew Conde
Reviews.Content: I got this for a bit of code on the go and just to browse.Does all this really nicely!One thing to consider is it says it charges by the normal mobile chargers, but I'm yet to find one that charges other than the plug that comes with it.Normal phone chargers only trickle charge it whilst its off. (Nexus 7 2012/2013, Nexus 4 and Raspberry Pi chargers only trickle it)

Reviews.Title: Very capable device.
Reviews.Author: Beer Shark
Reviews.Content: The overall build quality is nice.  It looks and feels like a well made device.  The keyboard is very good.  Monitor is nice enough (no complaints at all).  Small.  Lightweight.  Good battery life.The chromebook is not nearly as limited as some seem to believe.  Sure, you're not going to run R on it, but if you're looking at a computer in this price range, you more than likely aren't doing anything a chromebook cant do. And if you are in need of more than a chromebook, then you should already know that for sure.  That is, if you don't know a chromebook is too limited, then it isn't.

Reviews.Title: Gets the job done
Reviews.Author: Adam
Reviews.Content: I like the idea of a Chromebook, but have run into the limitations of chrome OS.  This product in particular is a little sluggish when it comes to loading websites, which surprised me.  Isnt that the main purpose of the Chromebooks??  Anyway, I just leave it under the couch, plugged in (with the new charger) and I always have an easy to grab computer.  It certainly beats trying to surf the web on my phone.  Netflix runs great.

Reviews.Title: Everything I Need, and Nothing More
Reviews.Author: Gilbert Perea
Reviews.Content: I purchased this computer because my Alienware M14x R2 recently broke, and I don't have money for such an investment so soon. So I looked around for cheap laptops that work good, and I came across this! I am NOT disappointed. It does everything fine and smooth. As long as you understand it's limits and respect them, it's perfect. Of course it's not going to play games or download applications, but it's gonna surf the web, type up documents, watch Youtube videos, etc... perfectly! As long as you don't need to download anything, this will work PERFECT for everyone! It's CHEAP, LOOKS GOOD, AND FUNCTIONS PERFECTLY! Just don't expect it to do what it's not made for!

Reviews.Title: An excellent product, really satisfied with my purchase
Reviews.Author: Ben Johnson
Reviews.Content: I haven't had this much fun using a laptop in a long time. The design is beautiful, the keyboard is impressive, and despite some of the negative comments I've seen about the trackpad, I find that it's a big step up from what I'm used to on my Windows 8 Ultrabook (though it's outclassed by trackpads on the much more expensive Apple machines). While I don't think this laptop can function as a primary laptop for all but the most casual PC users, don't underestimate what you can accomplish by utilizing cloud applications in the Chrome browser. I use the Cloud9 IDE for casual web development, Spotify to listen to my music, Netflix/Hulu for all of my TV needs, and Google WebApps for everything else. HP could have given the device a more powerful processor, but its performance is fine provided you don't try running 10+ tabs while streaming music or video. Being built specifically for the web, HP's Chromebook 11 is a focused, clean experience, and has surpassed my phone and tablet as my favorite personal device in just a short amount of time.

Reviews.Title: This is a beautiful laptop for the price with a fantastic screen, could use more speed but you can't have everything.
Reviews.Author: Ryan Smith "Photographer"
Reviews.Content: Almost everything I do now on a laptop is on the web, so a Chromebook is a great idea for me.  I'm a pro photographer, and I have my big desktop Mac and Windows server for storage for my real work. I can't stand doing photography work on a laptop, I need my 27 inch Thunderbolt display for real work.  The Chromebook lets me answer e-mail, add things to my calendar, use Gmail canned responses (which you can't do on a tablet), even work on my website with the new online IDE apps.  I like Shiftedit as well or better than Coda 2 on my Mac.  People who say you should just get a tablet instead of a Chromebook, they are a lot different, this is running real desktop Chrome with Flash and everything. The only problem is the speed, it needs a more powerful cpu and more ram, but it's good enough for what I need.  If they put a more modern ARM cpu in one of these it would be perfect, but it's good enough now. Give it an hour or so and it seems to get faster, I also updated to the Beta Chrome channel.Update: The more I use this the more cool things I find.  For example I use Pages on my Mac desktop, who needs Office.  Apple now has pages online which takes a little while to load, but let's you edit your Mac Pages docs right on the Chromebook!

Reviews.Title: Review of HP Chromebook 11
Reviews.Author: Michelle Cook
Reviews.Content: I rated his a five for many reasons.  It is fast - no wait time to come on or going to where I want to go.  It is very portable - small enough to fit in the ruck I carry even in the case I have for it, it is light and durable.  Since I got it, before Thanksgiving, it has been the only computer I have used and I use it every day.  It does all that I require of it and is the most enjoyable computer I have ever used.  My only problem with it has been getting used to using a touch pad, I had never used one before and it took me a little time to  get used to it.  I have recommended this Chromebook to all my friends and others.  I chose this computer after much research and my wife got it for me for Christmas (early).  One of the best things I have ever asked for.

Reviews.Title: wonderful computer
Reviews.Author: C. McFall "reader"
Reviews.Content: The Chromebook is a beautiful computer both aesthetically and operationally. Simple to unbox and start up almost instantaneously.  Bundling operations is ingenious. Keyboard feels good and operates efficiently.  Apps are abundant.  Screen is bright and beautiful. Plugged in a Microsoft wireless mouse and it started automatically. Unfortunately, I am 72 and have some vision problems. The screen and font size were too small for me to read comfortably.  However, with Amazon's exceptional customer service, I was able to send it back and order a Fire HD immediately which will better serve my basic needs for web surfing, email, streaming, music, news etc. I can move the device close enough to be able to see and read almost any page.  That being said, this is by far the best computer I have ever bought and Amazon has the best customer service I have ever experienced. (And I am a very picky customer---some would say anal; I say anal-YTICAL.)

Reviews.Title: Simply amazing
Reviews.Author: Israel Johnson
Reviews.Content: My last computer was a piece of crap. This Chromebook is everything I wanted and more. It's my first year in college and I needed something that I can carry in my backpack all day and it definitely wasn't that fat lenovo laptop. Google Docs is awesome and the 60 days of Google play is just perfect. This Chromebook is perfect for a student. It's cheap and is very good quality. That is the perfect combination and the consumers have realized that. You should definitely buy this Chromebook. You won't regret it.

Reviews.Title: For the price, it is perfect
Reviews.Author: Josephine Della Porta "working mom"
Reviews.Content: For this price, this is the best computer on the market by far. In my opinion this is the largest jump from Chromebook to Chromebook. This is my second Chromebook (my first was the Samsung Chromebook). The Samsung was great, but it wasn't really fast enough and felt very flimsy, so when I saw that HP had came out with a new Chromebook for the same great price; I sold my old Chromebook and upgraded to this one.Even with the same processor, this Chromebook feels faster and more responsive. The glossy plastic backed with magnesium is sturdy and feels premium. The screen is leaps and bounds better, and has very good viewing angles. The speakers behind the keyboard are a welcome improvement. The keyboard is very sturdy and really easy to type on. My only complaint is that it is not back lit. But overall, the laptop is very well built.In terms of the operating system; it takes some getting used to, but when you do it is just as good as any other laptop. Sure you can't run huge programs or hardcore game (if you need this then this computer is not for you), but for most other needs it does great. Google Docs makes it easy to type documents, and you can do that offline. For watching movies and videos it is perfect. For $279.99 this is the best laptop out there, and you really can't go wrong.

Reviews.Title: Great Computer for the Value
Reviews.Author: hallgirl
Reviews.Content: I had recently bought an ASUS Windows laptop and returned it because it seemed extremely laggy and slow.  Since most of what I use my home computer for is internet based I decided to give the Chromebook a whirl.  I decided on the HP Chromebook 11 first off because I liked the way it looked compared to the other Chromebooks in the same price range.  Amazon said it would be almost a month before it was shipped, but I had gotten an email a few days after my purchase saying it was in stock and would ship out, so don't let the estimated arrival dates sway you from purchasing.  I got the white book with the blue trim and it's very sharp looking.  I am use to my home or work laptop which are both windows based taking 5 minutes or longer to fully boot up.  The chromebook takes about 5 seconds (If that) to get to the login screen.  Once you open the browser, pages load extremely quick.  I have no issues with cloud storage and I also have a USB storage device which I also use to store and access files.  If your main reason for using a computer is for internet then you can't go wrong with the device, you will be happy you purchased!  The only con I would say is the length of the charger...could be another foot or two longer, but other than that no complaints :)

Reviews.Title: Two chromebooks returned, waiting on Third replacement
Reviews.Author: Elizabeth Norris
Reviews.Content: I really liked my Chromebook when it worked.  I've had to return two of them due to both no longer taking a charge with their charger.  If I could return it for a refund I would, but of course it's past 30 days since I purchased it.  I'm currently waiting on my third replacement, they say it will take about two weeks to arrive, but haven't given me a date yet. I'm so disappointed and frustrated with the whole situation.  I use this laptop for work, and the constant problems have been a serious issue for me.

Reviews.Title: Pretty Good
Reviews.Author: Shanda Williamson
Reviews.Content: Actually have two of these for my 10 year olds and they work great.  We had a couple of problems due to defective chargers, but Google Customer Service was FANTASTIC and got us a brand new units and chargers PLUS Google Play gift cards for our trouble.

Reviews.Title: HP Chromebook 11
Reviews.Author: M. Wire
Reviews.Content: Initially, I loved this little machine. The design is great, the screen is bright, the colors are very good, and the keyboard feels great(better than some high end ultrabooks I've tried). It was everything I expected out of a chromebook save for one thing, the battery life. Ultimately, I returned my chromebook as I was only getting a little under two and a half hours of battery life out of it.In my experience, there are only two short comings to the HP Chromebook 11, the lack of an SD card slot (I was aware, before I ordered it, that this unit did not have an SD card reader however, after using it, I realized that it needs one) and the battery life. I could forgive the first, but the latter... well I just need a bit more life out of it for this to be a useful edition to my work life.This is a great little system and I highly recommend it, it just did not work for my needs.Edit: I updated this review to avoid further confusion.

Reviews.Title: Second Chromebook. Just as happy as the first.
Reviews.Author: Jeremy Monat
Reviews.Content: I actually own the all black model and I have to say I love everything about the Chromebook. I have really bought into the Chrome OS system. I run beta and it runs pretty quick. I decided to buy this Chromebook over the Acer c720 for two main reasons. I personally use my Chromebook for surfing the web, watching movies, Netflix, and YouTube. I really think people should use the Chromebook 11's screen its pretty amazing for a sub-$300 computer. Another aspect in choosing which one is right for you is the basic specs. This Chromebook will run around 6 hours of use not including standby which is plenty for me (The average college school day).People who say that it is an obvious choice to pick the Acer c720 may be wrong considering how good the HP Chromebook 11 is. Also if someone who hasn't used a Chromebook before is reading this I suggest if you are interested try out a Chromebook. Buy one from Best Buy or a store with a decent return policy so that you can return the product if it doesn't fit you style.Pros:-Best screen in a Chromebook besides the Chrome Pixel-Personally like the track pad and keyboard better than the Samsung arm Chromebook (the other Chromebook I've owned since DEC 2012)-I also like it better than the C720 - but try it for yourself first!-Lightweight-No fans or noiseCons:-Takes slightly longer to charge (I think due to the USB charging)-Glossy (Could be a con or a good thing considering it looks awesome, but is a fingerprint magnet)-Chrome-cast does not work with ARM processors-Ubuntu is very limited in software with ARM(If you were interested in that aspect--You can run Open office/Libreoffice and other programs just nothing too intensive

Reviews.Title: Best computer i have ever used
Reviews.Author: amie lackie
Reviews.Content: Ive had a toshiba laptop for the past 3 years and i had more than enough problems with it. When it crashed (and i lost everything) for the second time i decided i needed a new device. I just graduated college and i am living on a budget, so i didnt have a lot of money to throw away on another laptop, so i looked into chromebook. Its simple and easy to use, which is good for me because i am pretty stupid when it comes to computers, and it looks and runs like a computer that is 3x as expensive. and i also want to give a shout out to the "cloud-like" system that automatically backs up everything i have on my computer! the only drawback i have to it is that i cant play the sims on it (im addicted) BUT my old toshiba is back up and running (slowly, but its running) so i can still use it for gaming.If you are a intense gamer, do not have access to either internet in some form (if you are an ethernet person, you will need a USB adapter, but mine only cost $21), you NEED a disc thingy, then i would go with a different computer. but if you are just using your computer for writing, web-surfing, video streaming, ext. then i would say go for it.

Reviews.Title: Chromebook 11- excellent build quality and phenomenal display
Reviews.Author: Jeff Stong
Reviews.Content: I've had my Chromebook 11 for 2 weeks.  I struggled at first thinking that it was just a crippled laptop and that a brain dead x86 laptop running Chrome and Google cloud services was the same thing.I was wrong.I found that I was grabbing the Chromebook over my Nexus 7 and also my 13" ultrabook.  The weight and display quality is just too much of a draw.  I agree with Cenile D. Mentia's review on the Processor- the machine would be faster with a Haswell chip but it would also probably gain 10 or more ounces and have a fan.  Once I got over the fact that I shouldn't leave more than about 8 windows open- I didn't have issues.  I suspect the issue is memory management in the OS and not the ARM architecture.  2GB of RAM for the OS should be plenty.  I'm confident Google will clean-up this issue.I look at this machine as the iPhone of Chromebooks.  What it does it does well.  It doesn't do everything.  If you are truly ready to kneel to Google and move to the Google ecosystem then this is a great machine to do it.  Give yourself a few days to adapt.  It's caused me to de-clutter how I work on my personal computing.  I don't have 4 major things running at once on the Chromebook while streaming Youtube and Netflix simultaneously- but who really needs that anyway.My only persistent gripe is the lack of SKYPE in Chrome.  I like the Outlook mail app more than Gmail- so if Microsoft is willing to support that in Chrome, hopefully SKYPE will come soon.  There's chatter on the web about Microsoft supporting SKYPE within the Outlook mail app which would be nice.Summary:- Gorgeous Build Quality- Well though-out- Not a Power User Laptop- but this isn't Chrome's place- Read about the Slimport capabilities- if you have a Nexus7, your adapters will work on that too.  It's about $12 for an adapter from Amazon.

Reviews.Title: It's good but you should know what you're buying before you buy
Reviews.Author: Huba "If you like my review please give a thu...
Reviews.Content: Personally for me I'm a student and I really do enjoy this chrome book it does the basics and that's exactly what I need and for the price I didn't find anything betterIt's thin its stylish it's light that's three things it has going for it that I could say no other laptop under $1000 probably has going for itLook you can't really do a lot it's basically chrome and some chrome apps from the chrome store and that's about it there is very minimal off-line support which may be an issue for some but for me I am personally and Wi-Fi 90% of the time so therefore I don't find it to be an issueOne thing that really does bother me is the fact that it came out one year after the Samsung chrome book but it still has the same internals of the Samsung chrome book meeting this a little slow for the its timeIt works fine with 1 2 3  tabs open but once you start getting two more tabs or having a couple things running at the same time like a calendar and Gmail and Facebook and then another chrome app it really starts to slow things down and it lags and it's not really meant for thatThe issue with the charger is no more I personally have bought this a while ago when it came out Google took a while to replace the charger but they have replaced it with a brand-new charger that charges it in around 2 to 3 hours which is very quick and they also sent a $25 Google play gift card for the inconvenience which is pretty niceOne big plus for this laptop is it has an amazing screen for the price it has the basic laptop resolution by the way to screen displays the colors it's amazing it definitely is better than most laptops that are even double or triple the priceIf you're a student or if you just need a spare computer lying around the house I just does basic Internet email Facebook stuff like that and you pretty much run Google stuff anyway like chrome and stuff I would definitely recommend thisI hope this helps you in making your decision if you like my view please give a thumbs up thanks

Reviews.Title: Great laptop + tablet hybrid !!
Reviews.Author: Patricio Hervas
Reviews.Content: I love this product. This is not a normal laptop but rather a sort of hybrid between laptop and tablet in my opinion, and you pretty much have to always be connected to wifi.In my case it's perfect (I'm head of a digital marketing agency). I visit clients all day. I can show websites, our designs, Facebook apps, etc. I could do that with a tablet before but with this I'm a lot more productive as I have a full size keyboard, I can edit easily excel files, bigger screen and a file system. The file system allows me to download a file, edit it and save it to a USB drive which I could not do with my iPad before.For many this will never be a laptop or tablet replacement since you cannot get many apps. But for me and many other people this might be the perfect device, and it's inexpensive !!

Reviews.Title: can't pry it from my kids' hands
Reviews.Author: J. Fiore
Reviews.Content: It's not going to win any speed contests, but it's light, has a very comfortable keyboard, and does a good job on what I think most people do on computers most of the time.  As one would expect, Google apps work flawlessly, as do Netflix, NBC Sports, and the other video streaming sites that I've tried.  USB charging is a very nice touch.On most days, I've been bringing this to work and leaving the MacBook Pro at home, and once I'm home for the day, the kids usually fight over it.Overall, I think that it's a great little device, especially for the price.

Reviews.Title: most poople will like it..........
Reviews.Author: Leon F. Davis
Reviews.Content: It is tricky..great fo Kindle, built in camera, Netflix . I think it the wave of the future. I keep finding reasons I'm happy with it. Self up dating, free virus protection , no windows works for me, maybe not for everybody............but close. I give it a cigar.

Reviews.Title: Best computer ever!
Reviews.Author: Biker
Reviews.Content: No problems whatsoever, flawless and timeless design, and runs extremely quickly. Chrome OS is the best in the business. What more could you ask for?

Reviews.Title: Very pleased parent
Reviews.Author: Eric Lynch
Reviews.Content: Ok let me start with the customer experience. I pre-ordered a White/blue HP Chromebook 11 from Amazon. Upon reflection I realized that my son would probably prefer White/Green so I chatted online with an Amazon Customer Service Representative. Response was quick and unfortunately accurate. Amazon did not at that time have White/Green available. The CSR offered an apology and offered to cancel the order which I accepted. I then purchased the desired color scheme from Google. Five stars for service Amazon.Now for the device itself. My son wanted a $2000 gaming laptop. I said no...LOL. I wanted him to have a laptop for school at school. He has a gaming desktop already and that is enough. He has an HP laptop too but it is too bulky to go into his backpack. This seemed like the perfect fit. I was correct. He has now recounted on a daily basis how helpful it is to have his own dedicated laptop for school at school. Their school has most of the curriculum online now and largely interfaces through Google docs for written assignments. He no longer needs to line up to share a laptop. Now it is just open his Chromebook and start working. He is getting homework assignments done at school during study session as well. I cannot think of a better way to spend $280. Thanks HP and Google. This fills a need with a high value product that is well constructed and cool looking. Five stars for that.

Reviews.Title: My favorite computer ever
Reviews.Author: Bri
Reviews.Content: I've owned Toshibas, Acers, HPs, Dells, and now Chromebook. I bought my Chromebook from Google only because I didn't want to wait for it, but I can tell you my family will be purchasing a second one soon. As someone who makes their living writing, and needs to be online all the time, this Chromebook is my favorite ever. At first I was worried that I would be writing "in the cloud" and terrified I'd lose my work for clients. No need. I can download the work from Google Docs, OpenOffice app or the new QuickOffice and save it on my computer. My previous laptop was crashing often and would take 20 minutes to an hour to boot and open Word. I can close this in a cafe, drive home, open it up, and everything is right there.The keyboard is a dream, it's easy to use, the keys feel great and I can work for hours.  It's small and thin but doesn't feel cheap and I've had people comment on how amazing it looks. The display is one of my favorite elements, it's bright and makes everything look great. I've watched several tv shows on this to test it out and they look fantastic. I know sound, especially with such a small computer, is an issue, but this little computer sounds great. I use headphones all the time, but the sound comes up nicely under the keyboard.  I'm accustomed to Harmon Kardon speakers on my old laptop, and those have a great sound, but this Chromebook does the trick and never disappoints. I've now increased my productivity tenfold because I can open it up and just start working immediately. Love using Gmail and everything else, none of that was a new thing for me, so this is seamless. I want to get my mom one soon because she has problems with viruses and malware, and this is the solution I know.UPDATE: Prior to the first charger being recalled, I had to send back my computer to Google because it started working. It refused to even display a charge light even when it sat plugged in all day. I was sent a replacement, and then eventually got the new charger. The latest computer displayed the same behavior after sitting for several days without being used. Then randomly it started working again when I plugged it in. I have noted others commenting about the same problem on the Google boards. My fix is to be sure I keep it plugged in and charged when I decide not to use it for several days. It's annoying though and Google wanted to replace it with a 2nd Chromebook. Which would make 3 I have had since October. Really. I still love it though.

Reviews.Title: My 3rd Chromebook and the best one yet
Reviews.Author: SteveG
Reviews.Content: This is the third Chromebook that I've owned.  I previously owned the Samsung XE303C12-A01US and the Acer C710-2826.  All three have 2GB of RAM and 16GB of eMMC storage.  The HP Chromebook 11 is the one I like the most.  The speed is the same as the Samsung, but not as fast as the Asus with the Celeron 847 CPU.  The HP has the best screen of the three (followed by the Acer and then the Samsung).  The HP has the best keyboard of the three (followed by the Samsung and the Acer).  The HP also has the best overall design.  I mostly do web browsing with a few tabs open and sometimes stream SiriusXM in the background.  Overall performance is fine.  I am a bit disappointed that the HP micro-USB charger will not charge my 2nd generation Nexus 7, but I'm not sure if that's due to HP's charger design or the Nexus 7's port design.  Unfortunately, I do not have any other micro-USB devices to try.  Overall, I'm liking the HP Chromebook 11.  The Chromebook to watch is the Acer C720 (with Haswell Celeron CPU and 4GB RAM), which has not yet been released.

Reviews.Title: Perfect for my needs and pocket book!
Reviews.Author: Andrew
Reviews.Content: I had read many reviews about this device and some made me nervous, such as those saying the processor was not up to the task....after using this device I have found that to be false.  I use my Chromebook for creating documents, surfing the web and watching videos (youtube, hulu, amazon, etc) and have had zero issues.  My assumption is those who made above metioned claims where probably not connected to a sufficiently fast wifi network.  Screen is bright and clear, keyboard works flawlessly, micro-usb charging is convenient, look/design is spot-on and speakers performed better than expected.  If I had one wish it would be for a little better battery life, but for the price I have no complaints.

Reviews.Title: Exceeding expectations
Reviews.Author: Maxim Kuvyrkov
Reviews.Content: I bought this ARM chromebook as a development board to run benchmarks, but very soon found myself using it for couch surfing, watching Netflix and reading emails at the breakfast. Then I went to a week-long conference -- and this is where Chromebook really shines.  With 4-5 hours battery life, tiny weight and very good screen this ARM chromebook easily replaced my 15" MacBook Pro, and I was smug walking around with just a tiny white-glossy case of chromebook instead of logging a backpack with MacBook and its charger.  For The Whole Day.

Reviews.Title: Very nice, Thank you!
Reviews.Author: Tamara Bauer
Reviews.Content: If you do not need to download programs, this is a great product.  I wish they were compatible with Microsoft office word and powerpoint.  Works beautifully for networking and emails....

Reviews.Title: Very Difficult to install wireless printer
Reviews.Author: D.P. "Happy"
Reviews.Content: So far it works well. It holds a charge well and has great colors and generally easy to use especially if you use Google and all of their websites. The company said there was a defective power cord that was replaced by warranty. The company contacted us and was shipped with the new part. The reason it received a 4 rating was because installing our wireless printer was a pain and I could not find a Customer Service number to call to get help installing my printer. I tried several times even plugging in the printer with the USB (nothing happened!) and by following the 'cloud' directions but my college kid came in town over a break and finished what I had started. The icon for the printer was in the computer but it did not work until she completed the final step. It was a pain. If I knew the OS was so different I would have gotten something I was familiar with (a regular laptop or netbook). My college kid recommended this device and finally helped set it up to print.

Reviews.Title: Stopped functioning after nearly 2 months of use
Reviews.Author: Everson
Reviews.Content: The laptop is not high end. I knew that going in however I did expect it to last me more than 2 months, especially after owning other laptops for 3 years... I think the battery went out but I couldn't fix the problem because the battery is totally inaccessible.

Reviews.Title: Disappointingly Slow
Reviews.Author: GT ACE "Say something about yourself!"
Reviews.Content: The HP Chromebook may get a higher rating here in Amazon.com but it's actual performance was dismal playing video! We tried watching a video on Viewster and then Crackle and finally Amazon Prime and the HP could no go for more than a few seconds before stopping and buffering again and again!I was running my new Samsung 11.6 Chromebook right next to my wife's new HP and the Samsung did not falter or buffer all the way through a movie I was running! Since my wife and I love to watch a lot of movies on our tablets or Chromebooks, the HP's performance is unacceptable and will be returned immediately!My wife is currently trying to decide between the Acer C720, which has apparently just replaced the Samsung 11.6 as the 1# Best Seller on Amazon, or a Samsung 11.6 like my new ChromebookThe bottom line is that the HP just doesn't  have the muscle to run the video we want. Otherwise it seemed to be a pretty nice device/

Reviews.Title: Bang for the buck
Reviews.Author: sgfnancy
Reviews.Content: I've used Macintosh computers since 1984. I've used their laptops for the last 15 or so years. When my MacBook Pro video card bit the dust a few weeks ago I was not in the mood nor the financial position to run out and buy a $2000 replacement, but, I need to keep writing, spreadsheeting, e-mailing and researching. I can do nothing but rave about the HP Chromebook 11 and the Chrome operating environment. It's fast, clean and efficient. Google Docs and Google Sheets lose all the fluff and clutter that has bloated Word and Excel over the decades. Pixlr nearly duplicates everything in Photoshop and certainly has everything I need. As far as the physical machine goes, I love the feel of the keyboard, the look of the screen and the fact that it makes absolutely no noise and generates virtually no heat. When people say Chromebooks can't "work", the only thing they can possibly be talking about is high-end photo editing including compositing and video editing. If that's the case, then, yeah...it's going to come up short. But, if you're a writer, researcher or office correspondent, don't feel this won't be enough machine for you. It's refreshing if you've worked with computers for the last 20 years to get back to a streamlined OS.

Reviews.Title: HP Chromebook 11
Reviews.Author: Gina Iaccino
Reviews.Content: This is perfect for "non-techies" as myself. I am a 49 year old woman; growing up in the 80's I was not focused on technology. There is no set up required, the chromebook was ready to use directly from the box it was shipped in. I am a huge web surfer, which this item makes it quick and simple to perform. The key board is large enough to type quickly and efficiently. The only downside is getting used to the idea of not having access to Microsoft Word. I have not tried to type a report, as my 16 year old daughter mentioned she misses the use of  MW.  I highly recommend this item for basic surfing and very basic computer needs. It is a great item for tweens, as well.

Reviews.Title: 90% satisfaction and easy use even in Japan with solid WiFi or your router available
Reviews.Author: yoshihira
Reviews.Content: I received and started to use this product in Tokyo, Japan, just 4 days after my placement of Yen settlement at amazon USA.First of all this product is light and thin enough for my nomad style use in cafe or other facilities.  Within my ordinary use of word processing, emailing, browsing web, etc., this device can provide sufficient processing and agility of boot-up.  In comparison with the former environment mere a few years ago, the usability of google drive & apps. has greatly evolved and the WiFi &/or carriers' service of 3G and LTE progressed tremendously in Japan.  So now I can find chromebooks are now the competitive alternative to Windows, Mac and Linux, and this item is the one evidence of this.  However,  I also have found three negative points of this product; (1) I tried to set bluetooth PAN with my iPhone5s, 3GS and Nexus7 but all in vain; (2) This chrome OS allow me to access tunein.com but the windows media streaming is not applicable to this OS; (3) A third party DVD drive can be recognized by this device but the contents for vob format can not be played, and curiously the same optical device with music CD can not be recognized by this OS; (4) Actual Battery life length is almost as the catalog spec, that makes me  greedy thinking "More 2 or 3 hours availability drives me 100% satisfied.  (Compatibility of micro USB power adopter-in is the merit, but 3 A power  source is rare.)  Anyway, I appreciate the design & usability of this product of hp 11 is pretty good.  Regards,

Reviews.Title: A+ on warranty service (once I talked to Google)
Reviews.Author: M. Bramel "map addict"
Reviews.Content: I can't say much about using this device, as I got it for my 10-year-old granddaughter--she seems to love it, and it seems pretty nice to me for what it does. We had a problem with the charging connection, which seemed to require a lot of wiggling around of the male plug in the Chromebook's receptacle. I probably missed something in who to call, but I started off with HP customer support, and had to talk to three people before someone realized that they don't service this device and I should have been talking to a Google Chrome Ninja for warranty support. With the right phone number for Google, I got quick acknowledgement of a hardware problem. They quickly got a replacement device in my hands, with prepaid shipping materials to get the old Chromebook back to them.
